text: TRANSLATOR'S PREFACE
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To arrive at a just estimate of a renowned man's character one must
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: judge it by the standards of his time, not ours. Judged by the standards
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of one century, the noblest characters of an earlier one lose much of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their luster; judged by the standards of to-day, there is probably no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: illustrious man of four or five centuries ago whose character could meet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the test at all points. But the character of Joan of Arc is unique.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It can be measured by the standards of all times without misgiving
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: or apprehension as to the result. Judged by any of them, it is still
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flawless, it is still ideally perfect; it still occupies the loftiest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: place possible to human attainment, a loftier one than has been reached
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by any other mere mortal.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When we reflect that her century was the brutalest, the wickedest, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rottenest in history since the darkest ages, we are lost in wonder at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the miracle of such a product from such a soil. The contrast between her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and her century is the contrast between day and night. She was truthful
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: when lying was the common speech of men; she was honest when honesty was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: become a lost virtue; she was a keeper of promises when the keeping of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a promise was expected of no one; she gave her great mind to great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thoughts and great purposes when other great minds wasted themselves
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon pretty fancies or upon poor ambitions; she was modest, and fine,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and delicate when to be loud and coarse might be said to be universal;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she was full of pity when a merciless cruelty was the rule; she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: steadfast when stability was unknown, and honorable in an age which had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forgotten what honor was; she was a rock of convictions in a time when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: men believed in nothing and scoffed at all things; she was unfailingly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: true to an age that was false to the core; she maintained her personal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dignity unimpaired in an age of fawnings and servilities; she was of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dauntless courage when hope and courage had perished in the hearts of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her nation; she was spotlessly pure in mind and body when society in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: highest places was foul in both--she was all these things in an age when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crime was the common business of lords and princes, and when the highest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: personages in Christendom were able to astonish even that infamous era
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and make it stand aghast at the spectacle of their atrocious lives black
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with unimaginable treacheries, butcheries, and beastialities.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was perhaps the only entirely unselfish person whose name has a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: place in profane history. No vestige or suggestion of self-seeking can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: be found in any word or deed of hers. When she had rescued her King
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from his vagabondage, and set his crown upon his head, she was offered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rewards and honors, but she refused them all, and would take nothing.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: All she would take for herself--if the King would grant it--was leave
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to go back to her village home, and tend her sheep again, and feel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her mother's arms about her, and be her housemaid and helper. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: selfishness of this unspoiled general of victorious armies, companion of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: princes, and idol of an applauding and grateful nation, reached but that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: far and no farther.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The work wrought by Joan of Arc may fairly be regarded as ranking any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: recorded in history, when one considers the conditions under which it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was undertaken, the obstacles in the way, and the means at her disposal.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Caesar carried conquests far, but he did it with the trained and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: confident veterans of Rome, and was a trained soldier himself; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Napoleon swept away the disciplined armies of Europe, but he also was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: trained soldier, and he began his work with patriot battalions inflamed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and inspired by the miracle-working new breath of Liberty breathed upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them by the Revolution--eager young apprentices to the splendid trade of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: war, not old and broken men-at-arms, despairing survivors of an age-long
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: accumulation of monotonous defeats; but Joan of Arc, a mere child in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: years, ignorant, unlettered, a poor village girl unknown and without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: influence, found a great nation lying in chains, helpless and hopeless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: under an alien domination, its treasury bankrupt, its soldiers
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: disheartened and dispersed, all spirit torpid, all courage dead in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hearts of the people through long years of foreign and domestic outrage
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and oppression, their King cowed, resigned to its fate, and preparing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to fly the country; and she laid her hand upon this nation, this corpse,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and it rose and followed her. She led it from victory to victory, she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: turned back the tide of the Hundred Years' War, she fatally crippled the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: English power, and died with the earned title of DELIVERER OF FRANCE,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: which she bears to this day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And for all reward, the French King, whom she had crowned, stood supine
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and indifferent, while French priests took the noble child, the most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: innocent, the most lovely, the most adorable the ages have produced, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: burned her alive at the stake.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: A PECULIARITY OF JOAN OF ARC'S HISTORY
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The details of the life of Joan of Arc form a biography which is unique
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: among the world's biographies in one respect: It is the only story of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: human life which comes to us under oath, the only one which comes to us
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from the witness-stand. The official records of the Great Trial of 1431,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and of the Process of Rehabilitation of a quarter of a century later,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: are still preserved in the National Archives of France, and they furnish
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with remarkable fullness the facts of her life. The history of no other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: life of that remote time is known with either the certainty or the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: comprehensiveness that attaches to hers.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Sieur Louis de Conte is faithful to her official history in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his Personal Recollections, and thus far his trustworthiness is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: unimpeachable; but his mass of added particulars must depend for credit
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon his word alone.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: THE SIEUR LOUIS DE CONTE
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To his Great-Great-Grand Nephews and Nieces
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This is the year 1492. I am eighty-two years of age. The things I am
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: going to tell you are things which I saw myself as a child and as a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: youth.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: In all the tales and songs and histories of Joan of Arc, which you and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the rest of the world read and sing and study in the books wrought in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the late invented art of printing, mention is made of me, the Sieur
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Louis de Conte--I was her page and secretary, I was with her from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: beginning until the end.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was reared in the same village with her. I played with her every day,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: when we were little children together, just as you play with your mates.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now that we perceive how great she was, now that her name fills the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: whole world, it seems strange that what I am saying is true; for it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as if a perishable paltry candle should speak of the eternal sun riding
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the heavens and say, "He was gossip and housemate to me when we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were candles together." And yet it is true, just as I say. I was her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: playmate, and I fought at her side in the wars; to this day I carry in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: my mind, fine and clear, the picture of that dear little figure, with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: breast bent to the flying horse's neck, charging at the head of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: armies of France, her hair streaming back, her silver mail plowing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: steadily deeper and deeper into the thick of the battle, sometimes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nearly drowned from sight by tossing heads of horses, uplifted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sword-arms, wind-blow plumes, and intercepting shields. I was with her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to the end; and when that black day came whose accusing shadow will lie
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always upon the memory of the mitered French slaves of England who were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her assassins, and upon France who stood idle and essayed no rescue, my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hand was the last she touched in life.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: As the years and the decades drifted by, and the spectacle of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: marvelous child's meteor flight across the war firmament of France
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and its extinction in the smoke-clouds of the stake receded deeper and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: deeper into the past and grew ever more strange, and wonderful, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: divine, and pathetic, I came to comprehend and recognize her at last for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: what she was--the most noble life that was ever born into this world save
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: only One.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: BOOK I IN DOMREMY
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 1 When Wolves Ran Free in Paris
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I, THE SIEUR LOUIS DE CONTE, was born in Neufchateau, on the 6th of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: January, 1410; that is to say, exactly two years before Joan of Arc was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: born in Domremy. My family had fled to those distant regions from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: neighborhood of Paris in the first years of the century. In politics
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they were Armagnacs--patriots; they were for our own French King, crazy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and impotent as he was. The Burgundian party, who were for the English,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had stripped them, and done it well. They took everything but my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: father's small nobility, and when he reached Neufchateau he reached it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in poverty and with a broken spirit. But the political atmosphere there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was the sort he liked, and that was something. He came to a region of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: comparative quiet; he left behind him a region peopled with furies,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: madmen, devils, where slaughter was a daily pastime and no man's life
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: safe for a moment. In Paris, mobs roared through the streets nightly,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sacking, burning, killing, unmolested, uninterrupted. The sun rose upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wrecked and smoking buildings, and upon mutilated corpses lying here,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there, and yonder about the streets, just as they fell, and stripped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: naked by thieves, the unholy gleaners after the mob. None had the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: courage to gather these dead for burial; they were left there to rot and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: create plagues.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And plagues they did create. Epidemics swept away the people like
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flies, and the burials were conducted secretly and by night, for public
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: funerals were not allowed, lest the revelation of the magnitude of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: plague's work unman the people and plunge them into despair. Then came,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: finally, the bitterest winter which had visited France in five hundred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: years. Famine, pestilence, slaughter, ice, snow--Paris had all these at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: once. The dead lay in heaps about the streets, and wolves entered the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: city in daylight and devoured them.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ah, France had fallen low--so low! For more than three quarters of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: century the English fangs had been bedded in her flesh, and so cowed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had her armies become by ceaseless rout and defeat that it was said and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: accepted that the mere sight of an English army was sufficient to put a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: French one to flight.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When I was five years old the prodigious disaster of Agincourt fell upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: France; and although the English King went home to enjoy his glory, he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: left the country prostrate and a prey to roving bands of Free Companions
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the service of the Burgundian party, and one of these bands came
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: raiding through Neufchateau one night, and by the light of our burning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: roof-thatch I saw all that were dear to me in this world (save an elder
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: brother, your ancestor, left behind with the court) butchered while
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they begged for mercy, and heard the butchers laugh at their prayers and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mimic their pleadings. I was overlooked, and escaped without hurt. When
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the savages were gone I crept out and cried the night away watching the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: burning houses; and I was all alone, except for the company of the dead
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the wounded, for the rest had taken flight and hidden themselves.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was sent to Domremy, to the priest, whose housekeeper became a loving
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mother to me. The priest, in the course of time, taught me to read and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: write, and he and I were the only persons in the village who possessed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this learning.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At the time that the house of this good priest, Guillaume Fronte, became
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: my home, I was six years old. We lived close by the village church, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the small garden of Joan's parents was behind the church. As to that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: family there were Jacques d'Arc the father, his wife Isabel Romee; three
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sons--Jacques, ten years old, Pierre, eight, and Jean, seven; Joan, four,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and her baby sister Catherine, about a year old. I had these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: children for playmates from the beginning. I had some other playmates
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: besides--particularly four boys: Pierre Morel, Etienne Roze, Noel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rainguesson, and Edmond Aubrey, whose father was maire at that time;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: also two girls, about Joan's age, who by and by became her favorites;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one was named Haumetter, the other was called Little Mengette. These
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: girls were common peasant children, like Joan herself. When they grew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: up, both married common laborers. Their estate was lowly enough, you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: see; yet a time came, many years after, when no passing stranger,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: howsoever great he might be, failed to go and pay his reverence to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: those two humble old women who had been honored in their youth by the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: friendship of Joan of Arc.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: These were all good children, just of the ordinary peasant type;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not bright, of course--you would not expect that--but good-hearted and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: companionable, obedient to their parents and the priest; and as they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: grew up they became properly stocked with narrowness and prejudices
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: got at second hand from their elders, and adopted without reserve; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: without examination also--which goes without saying. Their religion was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: inherited, their politics the same. John Huss and his sort might find
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fault with the Church, in Domremy it disturbed nobody's faith; and when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the split came, when I was fourteen, and we had three Popes at once,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nobody in Domremy was worried about how to choose among them--the Pope of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Rome was the right one, a Pope outside of Rome was no Pope at all.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Every human creature in the village was an Armagnac--a patriot--and if we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: children hotly hated nothing else in the world, we did certainly hate
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English and Burgundian name and polity in that way.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 2 The Fairy Tree of Domremy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: OUR DOMREMY was like any other humble little hamlet of that remote time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and region. It was a maze of crooked, narrow lanes and alleys shaded and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sheltered by the overhanging thatch roofs of the barnlike houses. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: houses were dimly lighted by wooden-shuttered windows--that is, holes in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the walls which served for windows. The floors were dirt, and there was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: very little furniture. Sheep and cattle grazing was the main industry;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all the young folks tended flocks.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The situation was beautiful. From one edge of the village a flowery
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: plain extended in a wide sweep to the river--the Meuse; from the rear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: edge of the village a grassy slope rose gradually, and at the top was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the great oak forest--a forest that was deep and gloomy and dense, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: full of interest for us children, for many murders had been done in it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by outlaws in old times, and in still earlier times prodigious dragons
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that spouted fire and poisonous vapors from their nostrils had their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: homes in there. In fact, one was still living in there in our own time.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was as long as a tree, and had a body as big around as a tierce, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: scales like overlapping great tiles, and deep ruby eyes as large as a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cavalier's hat, and an anchor-fluke on its tail as big as I don't know
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: what, but very big, even unusually so for a dragon, as everybody
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said who knew about dragons. It was thought that this dragon was of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: brilliant blue color, with gold mottlings, but no one had ever seen it,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: therefore this was not known to be so, it was only an opinion. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not my opinion; I think there is no sense in forming an opinion when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there is no evidence to form it on. If you build a person without any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bones in him he may look fair enough to the eye, but he will be limber
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and cannot stand up; and I consider that evidence is the bones of an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: opinion. But I will take up this matter more at large at another time,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and try to make the justness of my position appear. As to that dragon,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I always held the belief that its color was gold and without blue, for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that has always been the color of dragons. That this dragon lay but a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: little way within the wood at one time is shown by the fact that Pierre
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Morel was in there one day and smelt it, and recognized it by the smell.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It gives one a horrid idea of how near to us the deadliest danger can be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and we not suspect it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: In the earliest times a hundred knights from many remote places in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: earth would have gone in there one after another, to kill the dragon and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: get the reward, but in our time that method had gone out, and the priest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had become the one that abolished dragons. Pere Guillaume Fronte did it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in this case. He had a procession, with candles and incense and banners,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and marched around the edge of the wood and exorcised the dragon, and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was never heard of again, although it was the opinion of many that the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: smell never wholly passed away. Not that any had ever smelt the smell
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: again, for none had; it was only an opinion, like that other--and lacked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bones, you see. I know that the creature was there before the exorcism,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but whether it was there afterward or not is a thing which I cannot be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: so positive about.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: In a noble open space carpeted with grass on the high ground toward
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Vaucouleurs stood a most majestic beech tree with wide-reaching arms and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a grand spread of shade, and by it a limpid spring of cold water; and on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: summer days the children went there--oh, every summer for more than five
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hundred years--went there and sang and danced around the tree for hours
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: together, refreshing themselves at the spring from time to time, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was most lovely and enjoyable. Also they made wreaths of flowers and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hung them upon the tree and about the spring to please the fairies that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lived there; for they liked that, being idle innocent little creatures,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as all fairies are, and fond of anything delicate and pretty like wild
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flowers put together in that way. And in return for this attention the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fairies did any friendly thing they could for the children, such as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: keeping the spring always full and clear and cold, and driving away
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: serpents and insects that sting; and so there was never any unkindness
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: between the fairies and the children during more than five hundred

author: Twain, Mark

text: Now from time immemorial all children reared in Domremy were called the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Children of the Tree; and they loved that name, for it carried with it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a mystic privilege not granted to any others of the children of this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: world. Which was this: whenever one of these came to die, then beyond
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the vague and formless images drifting through his darkening mind rose
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soft and rich and fair a vision of the Tree--if all was well with his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soul. That was what some said. Others said the vision came in two ways:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: once as a warning, one or two years in advance of death, when the soul
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: winter aspect--then that soul was smitten with an awful fear. If
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: repentance came, and purity of life, the vision came again, this time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: vision was withheld, and it passed from life knowing its doom. Still
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: others said that the vision came but once, and then only to the sinless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dying forlorn in distant lands and pitifully longing for some last dear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: reminder of their home. And what reminder of it could go to their hearts
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: like the picture of the Tree that was the darling of their love and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: comrade of their joys and comforter of their small griefs all through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the divine days of their vanished youth?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now the several traditions were as I have said, some believing one and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: some another. One of them I knew to be the truth, and that was the last
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one. I do not say anything against the others; I think they were true,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but I only know that the last one was; and it is my thought that if one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: keep to the things he knows, and not trouble about the things which he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cannot be sure about, he will have the steadier mind for it--and there is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: profit in that. I know that when the Children of the Tree die in a far
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: land, then--if they be at peace with God--they turn their longing eyes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in a dream of golden light; and they see the bloomy mead sloping away to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the river, and to their perishing nostrils is blown faint and sweet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the fragrance of the flowers of home. And then the vision fades and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: passes--but they know, they know! and by their transfigured faces you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: come, and that it has come from heaven.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan and I believed alike about this matter. But Pierre Morel and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Jacques d'Arc, and many others believed that the vision appeared
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: twice--to a sinner. In fact, they and many others said they knew it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: gets most things at second hand in this world.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now one thing that does make it quite likely that there were really two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: apparitions of the Tree is this fact: From the most ancient times if one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fright, it was common for every one to whisper to his neighbor, "Ah, he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is in sin, and has got his warning." And the neighbor would shudder at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the thought and whisper back, "Yes, poor soul, he has seen the Tree."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Such evidences as these have their weight; they are not to be put
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: aside with a wave of the hand. A thing that is backed by the cumulative
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all the time; and if this continue and continue, it will some day become
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: authority--and authority is a bedded rock, and will abide.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: In my long life I have seen several cases where the tree appeared
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: announcing a death which was still far away; but in none of these was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the person in a state of sin. No; the apparition was in these cases
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: only a special grace; in place of deferring the tidings of that soul's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: redemption till the day of death, the apparition brought them long
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: before, and with them peace--peace that might no more be disturbed--the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eternal peace of God. I myself, old and broken, wait with serenity; for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I have seen the vision of the Tree. I have seen it, and am content.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: air--a solacing sweet air which has gone murmuring through my dreaming
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: spirit all my life when I was weary and troubled, resting me and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and flow, and waste away before that little band of heroes; we saw each
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: when that last surviving soul had passed.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: And now, in this solemn hush, the stranger gave Joan a pat or two on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: head and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Little maid--whom God keep!--you have brought me from death to life this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: night; now listen: here is your reward," and at that supreme time for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: such a heart-melting, soul-rousing surprise, without another word he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lifted up the most noble and pathetic voice that was ever heard, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: began to pour out the great Song of Roland!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Think of that, with a French audience all stirred up and ready. Oh,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: where was your spoken eloquence now! what was it to this! How fine he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: looked, how stately, how inspired, as he stood there with that mighty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: chant welling from his lips and his heart, his whole body transfigured,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and his rags along with it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Everybody rose and stood while he sang, and their faces glowed and their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eyes burned; and the tears came and flowed down their cheeks and their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bosoms to heave and pant; and moanings broke out, and deep ejaculations;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hand, and breathed his beautiful prayer with his paling pips, all burst
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: kisses.

text: Chapter 4 Joan Tames the Mad Man
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: ALL CHILDREN have nicknames, and we had ours. We got one apiece early,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and they stuck to us; but Joan was richer in this matter, for, as time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: went on, she earned a second, and then a third, and so on, and we gave
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them to her. First and last she had as many as half a dozen. Several
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of these she never lost. Peasant-girls are bashful naturally; but she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: surpassed the rule so far, and colored so easily, and was so easily
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: embarrassed in the presence of strangers, that we nicknamed her the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bashful. We were all patriots, but she was called the Patriot, because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: our warmest feeling for our country was cold beside hers. Also she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was called the Beautiful; and this was not merely because of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: extraordinary beauty of her face and form, but because of the loveliness
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of her character. These names she kept, and one other--the Brave.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We grew along up, in that plodding and peaceful region, and got to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: good-sized boys and girls--big enough, in fact, to begin to know as much
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about the wars raging perpetually to the west and north of us as our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: elders, and also to feel as stirred up over the occasional news from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: these red fields as they did. I remember certain of these days very
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: clearly. One Tuesday a crowd of us were romping and singing around the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Fairy Tree, and hanging garlands on it in memory of our lost little
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fairy friends, when Little Mengette cried out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Look! What is that?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When one exclaims like that in a way that shows astonishment and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: apprehension, he gets attention. All the panting breasts and flushed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: faces flocked together, and all the eager eyes were turned in one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: direction--down the slope, toward the village.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It's a black flag."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "A black flag! No--is it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You can see for yourself that it is nothing else."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is a black flag, sure! Now, has any ever seen the like of that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: before?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What can it mean?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Mean? It means something dreadful--what else?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That is nothing to the point; anybody knows that without the telling.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But what?--that is the question."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is a chance that he that bears it can answer as well as any that are
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: here, if you contain yourself till he comes."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "He runs well. Who is it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Some named one, some another; but presently all saw that it was Etienne
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Roze, called the Sunflower, because he had yellow hair and a round
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pock-marked face. His ancestors had been Germans some centuries ago.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He came straining up the slope, now and then projecting his flag-stick
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: aloft and giving his black symbol of woe a wave in the air, whilst all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eyes watched him, all tongues discussed him, and every heart beat faster
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and faster with impatience to know his news. At last he sprang among us,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and struck his flag-stick into the ground, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There! Stand there and represent France while I get my breath. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: needs no other flag now."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: All the giddy chatter stopped. It was as if one had announced a death.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: In that chilly hush there was no sound audible but the panting of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: breath-blown boy. When he was presently able to speak, he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Black news is come. A treaty has been made at Troyes between France
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the English and Burgundians. By it France is betrayed and delivered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over, tied hand and foot, to the enemy. It is the work of the Duke of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burgundy and that she-devil, the Queen of France. It marries Henry of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: England to Catharine of France--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Is not this a lie? Marries the daughter of France to the Butcher of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Agincourt? It is not to be believed. You have not heard aright."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If you cannot believe that, Jacques d'Arc, then you have a difficult
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: task indeed before you, for worse is to come. Any child that is born of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that marriage--if even a girl--is to inherit the thrones of both England
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and France, and this double ownership is to remain with its posterity
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forever!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now that is certainly a lie, for it runs counter to our Salic law, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: so is not legal and cannot have effect," said Edmond Aubrey, called the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Paladin, because of the armies he was always going to eat up some day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He would have said more, but he was drowned out by the clamors of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: others, who all burst into a fury over this feature of the treaty, all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: talking at once and nobody hearing anybody, until presently Haumette
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: persuaded them to be still, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is not fair to break him up so in his tale; pray let him go on.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: You find fault with his history because it seems to be lies. That were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: reason for satisfaction--that kind of lies--not discontent. Tell the rest,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Etienne."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There is but this to tell: Our King, Charles VI., is to reign until he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dies, then Henry V. of England is to be Regent of France until a child
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of his shall be old enough to--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That man is to reign over us--the Butcher? It is lies! all lies!" cried
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Paladin. "Besides, look you--what becomes of our Dauphin? What says
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the treaty about him?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Nothing. It takes away his throne and makes him an outcast."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then everybody shouted at once and said the news was a lie; and all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: began to get cheerful again, saying, "Our King would have to sign the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: treaty to make it good; and that he would not do, seeing how it serves
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his own son."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But the Sunflower said: "I will ask you this: Would the Queen sign a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: treaty disinheriting her son?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That viper? Certainly. Nobody is talking of her. Nobody expects better
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of her. There is no villainy she will stick at, if it feed her spite;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and she hates her son. Her signing it is of no consequence. The King
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: must sign."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I will ask you another thing. What is the King's condition? Mad, isn't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, and his people love him all the more for it. It brings him near to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them by his sufferings; and pitying him makes them love him."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You say right, Jacques d'Arc. Well, what would you of one that is mad?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Does he know what he does? No. Does he do what others make him do? Yes.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now, then, I tell you he has signed the treaty."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Who made him do it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You know, without my telling. The Queen."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then there was another uproar--everybody talking at once, and all heaping
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: execrations upon the Queen's head. Finally Jacques d'Arc said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But many reports come that are not true. Nothing so shameful as this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: has ever come before, nothing that cuts so deep, nothing that has
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dragged France so low; therefore there is hope that this tale is but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: another idle rumor. Where did you get it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
