title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: opinion of themselves than they had ever had before.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 5 Domremy Pillaged and Burned
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: THEY WERE peaceful and pleasant, those young and smoothly flowing days
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of ours; that is, that was the case as a rule, we being remote from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seat of war; but at intervals roving bands approached near enough for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: us to see the flush in the sky at night which marked where they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: burning some farmstead or village, and we all knew, or at least felt,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that some day they would come yet nearer, and we should have our turn.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This dull dread lay upon our spirits like a physical weight. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: greatly augmented a couple of years after the Treaty of Troyes.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was truly a dismal year for France. One day we had been over to have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one of our occasional pitched battles with those hated Burgundian boys
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the village of Maxey, and had been whipped, and were arriving on our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: side of the river after dark, bruised and weary, when we heard the bell
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ringing the tocsin. We ran all the way, and when we got to the square
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we found it crowded with the excited villagers, and weirdly lighted by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: smoking and flaring torches.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the steps of the church stood a stranger, a Burgundian priest, who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was telling the people news which made them weep, and rave, and rage,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and curse, by turns. He said our old mad King was dead, and that now we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and France and the crown were the property of an English baby lying in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his cradle in London. And he urged us to give that child our allegiance,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and be its faithful servants and well-wishers; and said we should now
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have a strong and stable government at last, and that in a little time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English armies would start on their last march, and it would be a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: brief one, for all that it would need to do would be to conquer what
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: odds and ends of our country yet remained under that rare and almost
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forgotten rag, the banner of France.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The people stormed and raged at him, and you could see dozens of them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stretch their fists above the sea of torch-lighted faces and shake them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: at him; and it was all a wild picture, and stirring to look at; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the priest was a first-rate part of it, too, for he stood there in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong glare and looked down on those angry people in the blandest and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: most indifferent way, so that while you wanted to burn him at the stake,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you still admired the aggravating coolness of him. And his winding-up
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was the coolest thing of all. For he told them how, at the funeral of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: our old King, the French King-at-Arms had broken his staff of office
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over the coffin of "Charles VI. and his dynasty," at the same time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: saying, in a loud voice, "God grant long life to Henry, King of France
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and England, our sovereign lord!" and then he asked them to join him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in a hearty Amen to that! The people were white with wrath, and it tied
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their tongues for the moment, and they could not speak. But Joan was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: standing close by, and she looked up in his face, and said in her sober,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: earnest way:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I would I might see thy head struck from thy body!"--then, after a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pause, and crossing herself--"if it were the will of God."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This is worth remembering, and I will tell you why: it is the only harsh
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: speech Joan ever uttered in her life. When I shall have revealed to you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the storms she went through, and the wrongs and persecutions, then you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will see that it was wonderful that she said but one bitter thing while
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she lived.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: From the day that that dreary news came we had one scare after another,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the marauders coming almost to our doors every now and then; so that we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lived in ever-increasing apprehension, and yet were somehow mercifully
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: spared from actual attack. But at last our turn did really come. This
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was in the spring of '28. The Burgundians swarmed in with a great noise,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in the middle of a dark night, and we had to jump up and fly for our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lives. We took the road to Neufchateau, and rushed along in the wildest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: disorder, everybody trying to get ahead, and thus the movements of all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were impeded; but Joan had a cool head--the only cool head there--and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she took command and brought order out of that chaos. She did her work
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: quickly and with decision and despatch, and soon turned the panic flight
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: into a quite steady-going march. You will grant that for so young a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: person, and a girl at that, this was a good piece of work.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was sixteen now, shapely and graceful, and of a beauty so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: extraordinary that I might allow myself any extravagance of language in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: describing it and yet have no fear of going beyond the truth. There was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in her face a sweetness and serenity and purity that justly reflected
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her spiritual nature. She was deeply religious, and this is a thing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: which sometimes gives a melancholy cast to a person's countenance, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was not so in her case. Her religion made her inwardly content and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: joyous; and if she was troubled at times, and showed the pain of it in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her face and bearing, it came of distress for her country; no part of it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was chargeable to her religion.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: A considerable part of our village was destroyed, and when it became
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: safe for us to venture back there we realized what other people had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: been suffering in all the various quarters of France for many years--yes,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: decades of years. For the first time we saw wrecked and smoke-blackened
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: homes, and in the lanes and alleys carcasses of dumb creatures that had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: been slaughtered in pure wantonness--among them calves and lambs that had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: been pets of the children; and it was pity to see the children lament
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over them.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And then, the taxes, the taxes! Everybody thought of that. That burden
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would fall heavy now in the commune's crippled condition, and all faces
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: grew long with the thought of it. Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Paying taxes with naught to pay them with is what the rest of France
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: has been doing these many years, but we never knew the bitterness of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that before. We shall know it now."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so she went on talking about it and growing more and more troubled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about it, until one could see that it was filling all her mind.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At last we came upon a dreadful object. It was the madman--hacked and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stabbed to death in his iron cage in the corner of the square. It was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bloody and dreadful sight. Hardly any of us young people had ever seen
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a man before who had lost his life by violence; so this cadaver had an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: awful fascination for us; we could not take our eyes from it. I mean, it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had that sort of fascination for all of us but one. That one was Joan.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She turned away in horror, and could not be persuaded to go near it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: again. There--it is a striking reminder that we are but creatures of use
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and custom; yes, and it is a reminder, too, of how harshly and unfairly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fate deals with us sometimes. For it was so ordered that the very ones
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: among us who were most fascinated with mutilated and bloody death were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to live their lives in peace, while that other, who had a native and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: deep horror of it, must presently go forth and have it as a familiar
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: spectacle every day on the field of battle.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: You may well believe that we had plenty of matter for talk now, since
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the raiding of our village seemed by long odds the greatest event that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had really ever occurred in the world; for although these dull peasants
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: may have thought they recognized the bigness of some of the previous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: occurrences that had filtered from the world's history dimly into their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: minds, the truth is that they hadn't. One biting little fact, visible
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to their eyes of flesh and felt in their own personal vitals, became
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: at once more prodigious to them than the grandest remote episode in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: world's history which they had got at second hand and by hearsay. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: amuses me now when I recall how our elders talked then. They fumed and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fretted in a fine fashion.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, yes," said old Jacques d'Arc, "things are come to a pretty pass,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: indeed! The King must be informed of this. It is time that he cease from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: idleness and dreaming, and get at his proper business." He meant our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: young disinherited King, the hunted refugee, Charles VII.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You say well," said the maire. "He should be informed, and that at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: once. It is an outrage that such things would be permitted. Why, we are
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not safe in our beds, and he taking his ease yonder. It shall be made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: known, indeed it shall--all France shall hear of it!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To hear them talk, one would have imagined that all the previous ten
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thousand sackings and burnings in France had been but fables, and this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one the only fact. It is always the way; words will answer as long as it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is only a person's neighbor who is in trouble, but when that person gets
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: into trouble himself, it is time that the King rise up and do something.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The big event filled us young people with talk, too. We let it flow in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a steady stream while we tended the flocks. We were beginning to feel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pretty important now, for I was eighteen and the other youths were from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one to four years older--young men, in fact. One day the Paladin was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: arrogantly criticizing the patriot generals of France and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Look at Dunois, Bastard of Orleans--call him a general! Just put me in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his place once--never mind what I would do, it is not for me to say,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I have no stomach for talk, my way is to act and let others do the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: talking--but just put me in his place once, that's all! And look at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Saintrailles--pooh! and that blustering La Hire, now what a general that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It shocked everybody to hear these great names so flippantly handled,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for to us these renowned soldiers were almost gods. In their far-off
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: splendor they rose upon our imaginations dim and huge, shadowy and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: awful, and it was a fearful thing to hear them spoken of as if they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mere men, and their acts open to comment and criticism. The color rose
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in Joan's face, and she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I know not how any can be so hardy as to use such words regarding these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sublime men, who are the very pillars of the French state, supporting it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with their strength and preserving it at daily cost of their blood. As
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for me, I could count myself honored past all deserving if I might be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: allowed but the privilege of looking upon them once--at a distance, I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mean, for it would not become one of my degree to approach them too
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: near."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Paladin was disconcerted for a moment, seeing by the faces around
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him that Joan had put into words what the others felt, then he pulled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his complacency together and fell to fault-finding again. Joan's brother
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Jean said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If you don't like what our generals do, why don't you go to the great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wars yourself and better their work? You are always talking about going
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to the wars, but you don't go."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Look you," said the Paladin, "it is easy to say that. Now I will tell
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you why I remain chafing here in a bloodless tranquillity which my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: reputation teaches you is repulsive to my nature. I do not go because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I am not a gentleman. That is the whole reason. What can one private
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldier do in a contest like this? Nothing. He is not permitted to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rise from the ranks. If I were a gentleman would I remain here? Not one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: moment. I can save France--ah, you may laugh, but I know what is in me, I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: know what is hid under this peasant cap. I can save France, and I stand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ready to do it, but not under these present conditions. If they want me,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: let them send for me; otherwise, let them take the consequences; I shall
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not budge but as an officer."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Alas, poor France--France is lost!" said Pierre d'Arc.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Since you sniff so at others, why don't you go to the wars yourself,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Pierre d'Arc?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, I haven't been sent for, either. I am no more a gentleman than you.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yet I will go; I promise to go. I promise to go as a private under your
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: orders--when you are sent for."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: Burgundian armies into the sea like flies."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will easily agree to that. Yes, he will march at the back of Captain
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: but organize under the Paladin's banner and go forth and rescue France.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: All said yes, except Jacques d'Arc, who said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I'll ask you to excuse me. It is pleasant to talk war, and I am with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you there, and I've always thought I should go soldiering about this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: time, but the look of our wrecked village and that carved-up and bloody
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: madman have taught me that I am not made for such work and such sights.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I could never be at home in that trade. Face swords and the big guns and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: death? It isn't in me. No, no; count me out. And besides, I'm the eldest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: The talk rattled on in the gay and careless fashion privileged to youth,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was going to answer when the King should require him to name his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Meaning Joan, though nobody suspected it at that time. If any had, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

text: that.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her what the question was, for her thought had been absent, and she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: heard none of this latter part of our talk. She supposed they wanted a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If the Dauphin, out of his grace and nobleness, should say to me, 'Now

author: Twain, Mark

text: that I am rich and am come to my own again, choose and have,' I should

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: taxed."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: laugh, but fell to thinking. We did not laugh; but there came a day when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: ALL THROUGH her childhood and up to the middle of her fourteenth year,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan had been the most light-hearted creature and the merriest in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: village, with a hop-skip-and-jump gait and a happy and catching laugh;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and this disposition, supplemented by her warm and sympathetic nature
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and frank and winning ways, had made her everybody's pet. She had been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a hot patriot all this time, and sometimes the war news had sobered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her spirits and wrung her heart and made her acquainted with tears, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always when these interruptions had run their course her spirits rose
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and she was her old self again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But now for a whole year and a half she had been mainly grave; not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: melancholy, but given to thought, abstraction, dreams. She was carrying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: France upon her heart, and she found the burden not light. I knew that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this was her trouble, but others attributed her abstraction to religious
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ecstasy, for she did not share her thinkings with the village at large,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: yet gave me glimpses of them, and so I knew, better than the rest, what
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was absorbing her interest. Many a time the idea crossed my mind that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she had a secret--a secret which she was keeping wholly to herself,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as well from me as from the others. This idea had come to me because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: several times she had cut a sentence in two and changed the subject when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: apparently she was on the verge of a revelation of some sort. I was to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: find this secret out, but not just yet.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The day after the conversation which I have been reporting we were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: together in the pastures and fell to talking about France, as usual. For
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her sake I had always talked hopefully before, but that was mere lying,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for really there was not anything to hang a rag of hope for France upon.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now it was such a pain to lie to her, and cost me such shame to offer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this treachery to one so snow-pure from lying and treachery, and even
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from suspicion of such baseness in others, as she was, that I was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: resolved to face about now and begin over again, and never insult her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: more with deception. I started on the new policy by saying--still opening
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: up with a small lie, of course, for habit is habit, and not to be flung
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out of the window by any man, but coaxed downstairs a step at a time:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, I have been thinking the thing all over last night, and have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: concluded that we have been in the wrong all this time; that the case
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of France is desperate; that it has been desperate ever since Agincourt;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and that to-day it is more than desperate, it is hopeless."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I did not look her in the face while I was saying it; it could not be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: expected of a person. To break her heart, to crush her hope with a so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: frankly brutal speech as that, without one charitable soft place in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it--it seemed a shameful thing, and it was. But when it was out, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: weight gone, and my conscience rising to the surface, I glanced at her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: face to see the result.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was none to see. At least none that I was expecting. There was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: barely perceptible suggestion of wonder in her serious eyes, but that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was all; and she said, in her simple and placid way:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The case of France hopeless? Why should you think that? Tell me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It is a most pleasant thing to find that what you thought would inflict
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a hurt upon one whom you honor, has not done it. I was relieved now,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and could say all my say without any furtivenesses and without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: embarrassment. So I began:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Let us put sentiment and patriotic illusions aside, and look at the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: facts in the face. What do they say? They speak as plainly as the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: figures in a merchant's account-book. One has only to add the two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: columns up to see that the French house is bankrupt, that one-half of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: its property is already in the English sheriff's hands and the other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: half in nobody's--except those of irresponsible raiders and robbers
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: confessing allegiance to nobody. Our King is shut up with his favorites
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and fools in inglorious idleness and poverty in a narrow little patch
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the kingdom--a sort of back lot, as one may say--and has no authority
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there or anywhere else, hasn't a farthing to his name, nor a regiment of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldiers; he is not fighting, he is not intending to fight, he means to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: make no further resistance; in truth, there is but one thing that he is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: intending to do--give the whole thing up, pitch his crown into the sewer,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and run away to Scotland. There are the facts. Are they correct?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, they are correct."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Then it is as I have said: one needs but to add them together in order

author: Twain, Mark

text: to realize what they mean."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She asked, in an ordinary, level tone:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What--that the case of France is hopeless?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Necessarily. In face of these facts, doubt of it is impossible."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "How can you say that? How can you feel like that?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "How can I? How could I think or feel in any other way, in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: circumstances? Joan, with these fatal figures before, you, have you

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: "Hope--oh, more than that! France will win her freedom and keep it. Do

author: Twain, Mark

text: not doubt it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It seemed to me that her clear intellect must surely be clouded to-day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, your heart, which worships France, is beguiling your head. You
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: are not perceiving the importance of these figures. Here--I want to make
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a picture of them, here on the ground with a stick. Now, this rough
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: outline is France. Through its middle, east and west, I draw a river."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, the Loire."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now, then, this whole northern half of the country is in the tight grip
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the English."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And this whole southern half is really in nobody's hands at all--as our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: King confesses by meditating desertion and flight to a foreign land.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: England has armies here; opposition is dead; she can assume full
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: possession whenever she may choose. In very truth, all France is gone,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: France is already lost, France has ceased to exist. What was France is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: now but a British province. Is this true?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Her voice was low, and just touched with emotion, but distinct:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, it is true."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Very well. Now add this clinching fact, and surely the sum is complete:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When have French soldiers won a victory? Scotch soldiers, under the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: French flag, have won a barren fight or two a few years back, but I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: am speaking of French ones. Since eight thousand Englishmen nearly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: annihilated sixty thousand Frenchmen a dozen years ago at Agincourt,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: French courage has been paralyzed. And so it is a common saying to-day
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that if you confront fifty French soldiers with five English ones, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: French will run."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is a pity, but even these things are true."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Then certainly the day for hoping is past."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I believed the case would be clear to her now. I thought it could not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fail to be clear to her, and that she would say, herself, that there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was no longer any ground for hope. But I was mistaken; and disappointed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: also. She said, without any doubt in her tone:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "France will rise again. You shall see."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Rise?--with this burden of English armies on her back!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "She will cast it off; she will trample it under foot!" This with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: spirit.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Without soldiers to fight with?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The drums will summon them. They will answer, and they will march."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "March to the rear, as usual?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No; to the front--ever to the front--always to the front! You shall see."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And the pauper King?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "He will mount his throne--he will wear his crown."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, of a truth this makes one's head dizzy. Why, if I could believe
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that in thirty years from now the English domination would be broken
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the French monarch's head find itself hooped with a real crown of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sovereignty--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Both will have happened before two years are sped."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Indeed? and who is going to perform all these sublime impossibilities?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "God."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was a reverent low note, but it rang clear.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: What could have put those strange ideas in her head? This question kept
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: running in my mind during two or three days. It was inevitable that I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: should think of madness. What other way was there to account for such
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: things? Grieving and brooding over the woes of France had weakened that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong mind, and filled it with fantastic phantoms--yes, that must be it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But I watched her, and tested her, and it was not so. Her eye was clear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and sane, her ways were natural, her speech direct and to the point. No,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there was nothing the matter with her mind; it was still the soundest in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the village and the best. She went on thinking for others, planning for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: others, sacrificing herself for others, just as always before. She went
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: on ministering to her sick and to her poor, and still stood ready to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: give the wayfarer her bed and content herself with the floor. There was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a secret somewhere, but madness was not the key to it. This was plain.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Now the key did presently come into my hands, and the way that it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: happened was this. You have heard all the world talk of this matter
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: which I am about to speak of, but you have not heard an eyewitness talk
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of it before.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was coming from over the ridge, one day--it was the 15th of May,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: '28--and when I got to the edge of the oak forest and was about to step
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out of it upon the turfy open space in which the haunted beech tree
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stood, I happened to cast a glance from cover, first--then I took a step
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: backward, and stood in the shelter and concealment of the foliage. For
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I had caught sight of Joan, and thought I would devise some sort of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: playful surprise for her. Think of it--that trivial conceit was neighbor,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with but a scarcely measurable interval of time between, to an event
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: destined to endure forever in histories and songs.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The day was overcast, and all that grassy space wherein the Tree stood
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lay in a soft rich shadow. Joan sat on a natural seat formed by gnarled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: great roots of the Tree. Her hands lay loosely, one reposing in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other, in her lap. Her head was bent a little toward the ground, and her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: air was that of one who is lost to thought, steeped in dreams, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not conscious of herself or of the world. And now I saw a most strange
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thing, for I saw a white shadow come slowly gliding along the grass
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: toward the Tree. It was of grand proportions--a robed form, with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wings--and the whiteness of this shadow was not like any other whiteness
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that we know of, except it be the whiteness of lightnings, but even
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the lightnings are not so intense as it was, for one can look at them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: without hurt, whereas this brilliancy was so blinding that it pained my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eyes and brought the water into them. I uncovered my head, perceiving
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that I was in the presence of something not of this world. My breath
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: grew faint and difficult, because of the terror and the awe that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: possessed me.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Another strange thing. The wood had been silent--smitten with that deep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stillness which comes when a storm-cloud darkens a forest, and the wild
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: creatures lose heart and are afraid; but now all the birds burst forth
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: into song, and the joy, the rapture, the ecstasy of it was beyond
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: belief; and was so eloquent and so moving, withal, that it was plain
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was an act of worship. With the first note of those birds Joan cast
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: herself upon her knees, and bent her head low and crossed her hands upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her breast.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She had not seen the shadow yet. Had the song of the birds told her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was coming? It had that look to me. Then the like of this must have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: happened before. Yes, there might be no doubt of that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The shadow approached Joan slowly; the extremity of it reached her,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flowed over her, clothed her in its awful splendor. In that immortal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: light her face, only humanly beautiful before, became divine; flooded
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with that transforming glory her mean peasant habit was become like to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the raiment of the sun-clothed children of God as we see them thronging
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the terraces of the Throne in our dreams and imaginings.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Presently she rose and stood, with her head still bowed a little, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with her arms down and the ends of her fingers lightly laced together in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: front of her; and standing so, all drenched with that wonderful light,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and yet apparently not knowing it, she seemed to listen--but I heard
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nothing. After a little she raised her head, and looked up as one might
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: look up toward the face of a giant, and then clasped her hands and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lifted them high, imploringly, and began to plead. I heard some of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: words. I heard her say:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But I am so young! oh, so young to leave my mother and my home and go
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out into the strange world to undertake a thing so great! Ah, how can I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: talk with men, be comrade with men?--soldiers! It would give me over to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: insult, and rude usage, and contempt. How can I go to the great wars,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and lead armies?--I a girl, and ignorant of such things, knowing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nothing of arms, nor how to mount a horse, nor ride it.... Yet--if it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: commanded--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Her voice sank a little, and was broken by sobs, and I made out no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: more of her words. Then I came to myself. I reflected that I had been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: intruding upon a mystery of God--and what might my punishment be? I was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: afraid, and went deeper into the wood. Then I carved a mark in the bark
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of a tree, saying to myself, it may be that I am dreaming and have not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and not dreaming, and see if this mark is still here; then I shall know.

author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 7 She Delivers the Divine Command
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I HEARD my name called. It was Joan's voice. It startled me, for how
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: could she know I was there? I said to myself, it is part of the dream;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it is all dream--voice, vision and all; the fairies have done this. So I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crossed myself and pronounced the name of God, to break the enchantment.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I knew I was awake now and free from the spell, for no spell can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: withstand this exorcism. Then I heard my name called again, and I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stepped at once from under cover, and there indeed was Joan, but not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: looking as she had looked in the dream. For she was not crying now, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was looking as she had used to look a year and a half before, when her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart was light and her spirits high. Her old-time energy and fire were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: back, and a something like exaltation showed itself in her face and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bearing. It was almost as if she had been in a trance all that time and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had come awake again. Really, it was just as if she had been away and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lost, and was come back to us at last; and I was so glad that I felt
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: like running to call everybody and have them flock around her and give
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her welcome. I ran to her excited and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, Joan, I've got such a wonderful thing to tell you about! You would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: never imagine it. I've had a dream, and in the dream I saw you right
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: here where you are standing now, and--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But she put up her hand and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It was not a dream."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It gave me a shock, and I began to feel afraid again.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Not a dream?" I said, "how can you know about it, Joan?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Are you dreaming now?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I--I suppose not. I think I am not."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Indeed you are not. I know you are not. And yow were not dreaming when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you cut the mark in the tree."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I felt myself turning cold with fright, for now I knew of a certainty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that I had not been dreaming, but had really been in the presence of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dread something not of this world. Then I remembered that my sinful feet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were upon holy ground--the ground where that celestial shadow had rested.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I moved quickly away, smitten to the bones with fear. Joan followed, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: the spring and I will tell you all my secret."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark
