title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Wait a little; I will soon come to that; then you will see."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But tell me one thing now; what was that awful shadow that I saw?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I will tell you, but do not be disturbed; you are not in danger. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the shadow of an archangel--Michael, the chief and lord of the armies of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: heaven."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I could but cross myself and tremble for having polluted that ground
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with my feet.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You were not afraid, Joan? Did you see his face--did you see his form?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes; I was not afraid, because this was not the first time. I was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: afraid the first time."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "When was that, Joan?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is nearly three years ago now."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "So long? Have you seen him many times?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, many times."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is this, then, that has changed you; it was this that made you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thoughtful and not as you were before. I see it now. Why did you not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tell us about it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It was not permitted. It is permitted now, and soon I shall tell all.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But only you, now. It must remain a secret for a few days still."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Has none seen that white shadow before but me?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No one. It has fallen upon me before when you and others were present,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but none could see it. To-day it has been otherwise, and I was told why;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but it will not be visible again to any."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It was a sign to me, then--and a sign with a meaning of some kind?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, but I may not speak of that."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Strange--that that dazzling light could rest upon an object before one's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eyes and not be visible."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "With it comes speech, also. Several saints come, attended by myriads
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of angels, and they speak to me; I hear their voices, but others do not.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They are very dear to me--my Voices; that is what I call them to myself."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, what do they tell you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "All manner of things--about France, I mean."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What things have they been used to tell you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She sighed, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Disasters--only disasters, and misfortunes, and humiliation. There was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: naught else to foretell."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They spoke of them to you beforehand?" "Yes. So that I knew what was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: going to happen before it happened. It made me grave--as you saw. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: could not be otherwise. But always there was a word of hope, too. More
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: than that: France was to be rescued, and made great and free again. But
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: how and by whom--that was not told. Not until to-day." As she said those
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: last words a sudden deep glow shone in her eyes, which I was to see
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there many times in after-days when the bugles sounded the charge and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: learn to call it the battle-light. Her breast heaved, and the color
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rose in her face. "But to-day I know. God has chosen the meanest of His
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: creatures for this work; and by His command, and in His protection, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by His strength, not mine, I am to lead His armies, and win back France,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and set the crown upon the head of His servant that is Dauphin and shall
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: be King."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was amazed, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You, Joan? You, a child, lead armies?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes. For one little moment or two the thought crushed me; for it is as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you say--I am only a child; a child and ignorant--ignorant of everything
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that pertains to war, and not fitted for the rough life of camps and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: companionship of soldiers. But those weak moments passed; they will not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: come again. I am enlisted, I will not turn back, God helping me, till
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English grip is loosed from the throat of France. My Voices have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: never told me lies, they have not lied to-day. They say I am to go to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Robert de Baudricourt, governor of Vaucouleurs, and he will give me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: men-at-arms for escort and send me to the King. A year from now a blow
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will be struck which will be the beginning of the end, and the end will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: follow swiftly."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Where will it be struck?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My Voices have not said; nor what will happen this present year, before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it is struck. It is appointed me to strike it, that is all I know; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: follow it with others, sharp and swift, undoing in ten weeks England's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: long years of costly labor, and setting the crown upon the Dauphin's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: head--for such is God's will; my Voices have said it, and shall I doubt
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it? No; it will be as they have said, for they say only that which is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: true."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: These were tremendous sayings. They were impossibilities to my reason,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but to my heart they rang true; and so, while my reason doubted, my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart believed--believed, and held fast to the belief from that day.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Presently I said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, I believe the things which you have said, and now I am glad that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I am to march with you to the great wars--that is, if it is with you I am
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to march when I go."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She looked surprised, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is true that you will be with me when I go to the wars, but how did
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you know?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I shall march with you, and so also will Jean and Pierre, but not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Jacques."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "All true--it is so ordered, as was revealed to me lately, but I did not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: know until to-day that the marching would be with me, or that I should
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: march at all. How did you know these things?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I told her when it was that she had said them. But she did not remember
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about it. So then I knew that she had been asleep, or in a trance or an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ecstasy of some kind, at that time. She bade me keep these and the other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: revelations to myself for the present, and I said I would, and kept the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: faith I promised.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: None who met Joan that day failed to notice the change that had come
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over her. She moved and spoke with energy and decision; there was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a strange new fire in her eye, and also a something wholly new and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: remarkable in her carriage and in the set of her head. This new light in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the eye and this new bearing were born of the authority and leadership
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: which had this day been vested in her by the decree of God, and they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: asserted that authority as plainly as speech could have done it, yet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: without ostentation or bravado. This calm consciousness of command, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: calm unconscious outward expression of it, remained with her thenceforth
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: until her mission was accomplished.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Like the other villagers, she had always accorded me the deference due
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: my rank; but now, without word said on either side, she and I changed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: places; she gave orders, not suggestions. I received them with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: deference due a superior, and obeyed them without comment. In the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: evening she said to me:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I leave before dawn. No one will know it but you. I go to speak with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the governor of Vaucouleurs as commanded, who will despise me and treat
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: me rudely, and perhaps refuse my prayer at this time. I go first to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Burey, to persuade my uncle Laxart to go with me, it not being meet that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I go alone. I may need you in Vaucouleurs; for if the governor will not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: receive me I will dictate a letter to him, and so must have some one by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: me who knows the art of how to write and spell the words. You will go
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from here to-morrow in the afternoon, and remain in Vaucouleurs until I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: need you."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I said I would obey, and she went her way. You see how clear a head she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had, and what a just and level judgment. She did not order me to go with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her; no, she would not subject her good name to gossiping remark. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: knew that the governor, being a noble, would grant me, another noble,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: audience; but no, you see, she would not have that, either. A poor
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: peasant-girl presenting a petition through a young nobleman--how would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that look? She always protected her modesty from hurt; and so, for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: reward, she carried her good name unsmirched to the end. I knew what I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: must do now, if I would have her approval: go to Vaucouleurs, keep out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of her sight, and be ready when wanted.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I went the next afternoon, and took an obscure lodging; the next day I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: called at the castle and paid my respects to the governor, who invited
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: me to dine with him at noon of the following day. He was an ideal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldier of the time; tall, brawny, gray-headed, rough, full of strange
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: oaths acquired here and there and yonder in the wars and treasured as if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they were decorations. He had been used to the camp all his life, and to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his notion war was God's best gift to man. He had his steel cuirass on,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and wore boots that came above his knees, and was equipped with a huge
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sword; and when I looked at this martial figure, and heard the marvelous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: oaths, and guessed how little of poetry and sentiment might be looked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for in this quarter, I hoped the little peasant-girl would not get the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: privilege of confronting this battery, but would have to content herself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with the dictated letter.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I came again to the castle the next day at noon, and was conducted to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the great dining-hall and seated by the side of the governor at a small
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: table which was raised a couple of steps higher than the general table.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At the small table sat several other guests besides myself, and at the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: general table sat the chief officers of the garrison. At the entrance
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: door stood a guard of halberdiers, in morion and breastplate.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: As for talk, there was but one topic, of course--the desperate situation
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of France. There was a rumor, some one said, that Salisbury was making
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: preparations to march against Orleans. It raised a turmoil of excited
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: conversation, and opinions fell thick and fast. Some believed he would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: march at once, others that he could not accomplish the investment before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fall, others that the siege would be long, and bravely contested; but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: silence. Every man seemed to sink himself in his own thoughts, and to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forget where he was. This sudden and profound stillness, where before
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: servant and whispered something to the governor, who said:

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Would talk with me?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, your Excellency."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "H'm! A strange idea, certainly. Bring them in."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was Joan and her uncle Laxart. At the spectacle of the great people
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the courage oozed out of the poor old peasant and he stopped midway and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would come no further, but remained there with his red nightcap crushed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in his hands and bowing humbly here, there, and everywhere, stupefied
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with embarrassment and fear. But Joan came steadily forward, erect and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, what is your errand, my child?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My message is to you, Robert de Baudricourt, governor of Vaucouleurs,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and it is this: that you will send and tell the Dauphin to wait and not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: give battle to his enemies, for God will presently send him help."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This strange speech amazed the company, and many murmured, "The poor
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: young thing is demented." The governor scowled, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What nonsense is this? The King--or the Dauphin, as you call him--needs
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: no message of that sort. He will wait, give yourself no uneasiness as to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that. What further do you desire to say to me?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "This. To beg that you will give me an escort of men-at-arms and send me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to the Dauphin."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What for?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That he may make me his general, for it is appointed that I shall drive
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English out of France, and set the crown upon his head."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What--you? Why, you are but a child!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yet am I appointed to do it, nevertheless."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Indeed! And when will all this happen?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Next year he will be crowned, and after that will remain master of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: France."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was a great and general burst of laughter, and when it had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: subsided the governor said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Who has sent you with these extravagant messages?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My Lord."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What Lord?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The King of Heaven."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Many murmured, "Ah, poor thing, poor thing!" and others, "Ah, her mind
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is but a wreck!" The governor hailed Laxart, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Harkye!--take this mad child home and whip her soundly. That is the best
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cure for her ailment."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: As Joan was moving away she turned and said, with simplicity:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You refuse me the soldiers, I know not why, for it is my Lord that has
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: commanded you. Yes, it is He that has made the command; therefore I must
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: come again, and yet again; then I shall have the men-at-arms."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was a great deal of wondering talk, after she was gone; and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: guards and servants passed the talk to the town, the town passed it to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the country; Domremy was already buzzing with it when we got back.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 8 Why the Scorners Relented
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: HUMAN NATURE is the same everywhere: it defies success, it has nothing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but scorn for defeat. The village considered that Joan had disgraced it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with her grotesque performance and its ridiculous failure; so all the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tongues were busy with the matter, and as bilious and bitter as they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were busy; insomuch that if the tongues had been teeth she would not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have survived her persecutions. Those persons who did not scold did what
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was worse and harder to bear; for they ridiculed her, and mocked at her,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and ceased neither day nor night from their witticisms and jeerings and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: laughter. Haumette and Little Mengette and I stood by her, but the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: storm was too strong for her other friends, and they avoided her, being
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ashamed to be seen with her because she was so unpopular, and because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the sting of the taunts that assailed them on her account. She shed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tears in secret, but none in public. In public she carried herself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with serenity, and showed no distress, nor any resentment--conduct which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: should have softened the feeling against her, but it did not. Her father
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was so incensed that he could not talk in measured terms about her wild
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: project of going to the wars like a man. He had dreamed of her doing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: such a thing, some time before, and now he remembered that dream with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: apprehension and anger, and said that rather than see her unsex herself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and go away with the armies, he would require her brothers to drown her;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and that if they should refuse, he would do it with his own hands.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But none of these things shook her purpose in the least. Her parents
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: kept a strict watch upon her to keep her from leaving the village, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she said her time was not yet; that when the time to go was come she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: should know it, and then the keepers would watch in vain.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The summer wasted along; and when it was seen that her purpose continued
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: steadfast, the parents were glad of a chance which finally offered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: itself for bringing her projects to an end through marriage. The Paladin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had the effrontery to pretend that she had engaged herself to him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: several years before, and now he claimed a ratification of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: engagement.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She said his statement was not true, and refused to marry him. She was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cited to appear before the ecclesiastical court at Toul to answer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for her perversity; when she declined to have counsel, and elected to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: conduct her case herself, her parents and all her ill-wishers rejoiced,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and looked upon her as already defeated. And that was natural enough;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for who would expect that an ignorant peasant-girl of sixteen would be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: otherwise than frightened and tongue-tied when standing for the first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: time in presence of the practised doctors of the law, and surrounded
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by the cold solemnities of a court? Yet all these people were mistaken.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They flocked to Toul to see and enjoy this fright and embarrassment
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and defeat, and they had their trouble for their pains. She was modest,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tranquil, and quite at her ease. She called no witnesses, saying she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would content herself with examining the witnesses for the prosecution.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When they had testified, she rose and reviewed their testimony in a few
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: words, pronounced it vague, confused, and of no force, then she placed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Paladin again on the stand and began to search him. His previous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: testimony went rag by rag to ruin under her ingenious hands, until at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: last he stood bare, so to speak, he that had come so richly clothed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in fraud and falsehood. His counsel began an argument, but the court
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: declined to hear it, and threw out the case, adding a few words of grave
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: compliment for Joan, and referring to her as "this marvelous child."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: After this victory, with this high praise from so imposing a source
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: added, the fickle village turned again, and gave Joan countenance,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: compliment, and peace. Her mother took her back to her heart, and even
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her father relented and said he was proud of her. But the time hung
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: heavy on her hands, nevertheless, for the siege of Orleans was begun,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the clouds lowered darker and darker over France, and still her Voices
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said wait, and gave her no direct commands. The winter set in, and wore
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tediously along; but at last there was a change.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: BOOK II IN COURT AND CAMP
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark
