text: Chapter 1 Joan Says Good-By
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: THE 5th of January, 1429, Joan came to me with her uncle Laxart, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The time is come. My Voices are not vague now, but clear, and they have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: told me what to do. In two months I shall be with the Dauphin."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Her spirits were high, and her bearing martial. I caught the infection
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and felt a great impulse stirring in me that was like what one feels
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: when he hears the roll of the drums and the tramp of marching men.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I believe it," I said.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I also believe it," said Laxart. "If she had told me before, that she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was commanded of God to rescue France, I should not have believed; I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: should have let her seek the governor by her own ways and held myself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: clear of meddling in the matter, not doubting she was mad. But I have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seen her stand before those nobles and mighty men unafraid, and say her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: say; and she had not been able to do that but by the help of God. That
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I know. Therefore with all humbleness I am at her command, to do with me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as she will."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My uncle is very good to me," Joan said. "I sent and asked him to come
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and persuade my mother to let him take me home with him to tend his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wife, who is not well. It is arranged, and we go at dawn to-morrow. From
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his house I shall go soon to Vaucouleurs, and wait and strive until my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: prayer is granted. Who were the two cavaliers who sat to your left at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the governor's table that day?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "One was the Sieur Jean de Novelonpont de Metz, the other the Sieur
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bertrand de Poulengy."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Good metal--good metal, both. I marked them for men of mine.... What is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it I see in your face? Doubt?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was teaching myself to speak the truth to her, not trimming it or
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: polishing it; so I said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They considered you out of your head, and said so. It is true they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pitied you for being in such misfortune, but still they held you to be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mad."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This did not seem to trouble her in any way or wound her. She only said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The wise change their minds when they perceive that they have been in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: error. These will. They will march with me. I shall see them presently..
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: .. You seem to doubt again? Do you doubt?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "N-no. Not now. I was remembering that it was a year ago, and that they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: did not belong here, but only chanced to stop a day on their journey."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They will come again. But as to matters now in hand; I came to leave
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with you some instructions. You will follow me in a few days. Order your
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: affairs, for you will be absent long."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Will Jean and Pierre go with me?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No; they would refuse now, but presently they will come, and with them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they will bring my parents' blessing, and likewise their consent that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I take up my mission. I shall be stronger, then--stronger for that; for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lack of it I am weak now." She paused a little while, and the tears
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: gathered in her eyes; then she went on: "I would say good-by to Little
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Mengette. Bring her outside the village at dawn; she must go with me a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: little of the way--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And Haumette?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She broke down and began to cry, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No, oh, no--she is too dear to me, I could not bear it, knowing I should
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: never look upon her face again."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Next morning I brought Mengette, and we four walked along the road in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the cold dawn till the village was far behind; then the two girls said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their good-bys, clinging about each other's neck, and pouring out their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: grief in loving words and tears, a pitiful sight to see. And Joan took
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one long look back upon the distant village, and the Fairy Tree, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: oak forest, and the flowery plain, and the river, as if she was trying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to print these scenes on her memory so that they would abide there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always and not fade, for she knew she would not see them any more in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this life; then she turned, and went from us, sobbing bitterly. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her birthday and mine. She was seventeen years old.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 2 The Governor Speeds Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: After a few days, Laxart took Joan to Vaucouleurs, and found lodging
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and guardianship for her with Catherine Royer, a wheelwright's wife, an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: honest and good woman. Joan went to mass regularly, she helped do the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: housework, earning her keep in that way, and if any wished to talk
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with her about her mission--and many did--she talked freely, making no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: concealments regarding the matter now. I was soon housed near by, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: witnessed the effects which followed. At once the tidings spread that a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: young girl was come who was appointed of God to save France. The common
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: people flocked in crowds to look at her and speak with her, and her fair
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: young loveliness won the half of their belief, and her deep earnestness
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and transparent sincerity won the other half. The well-to-do remained
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: away and scoffed, but that is their way.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Next, a prophecy of Merlin's, more than eight hundred years old, was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: called to mind, which said that in a far future time France would be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lost by a woman and restored by a woman. France was now, for the first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: time, lost--and by a woman, Isabel of Bavaria, her base Queen; doubtless
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this fair and pure young girl was commissioned of Heaven to complete the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: prophecy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This gave the growing interest a new and powerful impulse; the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: excitement rose higher and higher, and hope and faith along with it; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: so from Vaucouleurs wave after wave of this inspiring enthusiasm
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flowed out over the land, far and wide, invading all the villages and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: refreshing and revivifying the perishing children of France; and from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: these villages came people who wanted to see for themselves, hear for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: themselves; and they did see and hear, and believe. They filled the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: town; they more than filled it; inns and lodgings were packed, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: yet half of the inflow had to go without shelter. And still they came,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: winter as it was, for when a man's soul is starving, what does he care
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for meat and roof so he can but get that nobler hunger fed? Day after
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: day, and still day after day the great tide rose. Domremy was dazed,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: amazed, stupefied, and said to itself, "Was this world-wonder in our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: familiar midst all these years and we too dull to see it?" Jean and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Pierre went out from the village, stared at and envied like the great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and fortunate of the earth, and their progress to Vaucouleurs was like a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: triumph, all the country-side flocking to see and salute the brothers
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of one with whom angels had spoken face to face, and into whose hands by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: command of God they had delivered the destinies of France.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The brothers brought the parents' blessing and godspeed to Joan, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their promise to bring it to her in person later; and so, with this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: culminating happiness in her heart and the high hope it inspired, she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: went and confronted the governor again. But he was no more tractable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: than he had been before. He refused to send her to the King. She was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: disappointed, but in no degree discouraged. She said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I must still come to you until I get the men-at-arms; for so it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: commanded, and I may not disobey. I must go to the Dauphin, though I go
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: on my knees."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I and the two brothers were with Joan daily, to see the people that came
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and hear what they said; and one day, sure enough, the Sieur Jean de
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Metz came. He talked with her in a petting and playful way, as one talks
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with children, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What are you doing here, my little maid? Will they drive the King out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of France, and shall we all turn English?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She answered him in her tranquil, serious way:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I am come to bid Robert de Baudricourt take or send me to the King, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he does not heed my words."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, you have an admirable persistence, truly; a whole year has not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: turned you from your wish. I saw you when you came before."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan said, as tranquilly as before:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is not a wish, it is a purpose. He will grant it. I can wait."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, perhaps it will not be wise to make too sure of that, my child.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: These governors are stubborn people to deal with. In case he shall not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: grant your prayer--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "He will grant it. He must. It is not a matter of choice."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The gentleman's playful mood began to disappear--one could see that, by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his face. Joan's earnestness was affecting him. It always happened that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: people who began in jest with her ended by being in earnest. They soon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: began to perceive depths in her that they had not suspected; and then
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her manifest sincerity and the rocklike steadfastness of her convictions
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were forces which cowed levity, and it could not maintain its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: self-respect in their presence. The Sieur de Metz was thoughtful for a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: moment or two, then he began, quite soberly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Is it necessary that you go to the King soon?--that is, I mean--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Before Mid-Lent, even though I wear away my legs to the knees!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She said it with that sort of repressed fieriness that means so much
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: when a person's heart is in a thing. You could see the response in that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nobleman's face; you could see his eye light up; there was sympathy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there. He said, most earnestly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "God knows I think you should have the men-at-arms, and that somewhat
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would come of it. What is it that you would do? What is your hope and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: purpose?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "To rescue France. And it is appointed that I shall do it. For no one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: else in the world, neither kings, nor dukes, no any other, can recover
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the kingdom of France, and there is no help but in me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The words had a pleading and pathetic sound, and they touched that good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nobleman. I saw it plainly. Joan dropped her voice a little, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But indeed I would rather spin with my poor mother, for this is not my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: calling; but I must go and do it, for it is my Lord's will."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Who is your Lord?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "He is God."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then the Sieur de Metz, following the impressive old feudal fashion,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: knelt and laid his hands within Joan's in sign of fealty, and made oath
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that by God's help he himself would take her to the king.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The next day came the Sieur Bertrand de Poulengy, and he also
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pledged his oath and knightly honor to abide with her and follow her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: witherosever she might lead.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This day, too, toward evening, a great rumor went flying abroad through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the town--namely, that the very governor himself was going to visit the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: young girl in her humble lodgings. So in the morning the streets and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lanes were packed with people waiting to see if this strange thing would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: indeed happen. And happen it did. The governor rode in state, attended
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by his guards, and the news of it went everywhere, and made a great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sensation, and modified the scoffings of the people of quality and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: raised Joan's credit higher than ever.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The governor had made up his mind to one thing: Joan was either a witch
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: or a saint, and he meant to find out which it was. So he brought a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: priest with him to exorcise the devil that was in her in case there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was one there. The priest performed his office, but found no devil. He
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: merely hurt Joan's feelings and offended her piety without need, for he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had already confessed her before this, and should have known, if he knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: anything, that devils cannot abide the confessional, but utter cries
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of anguish and the most profane and furious cursings whenever they are
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: confronted with that holy office.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The governor went away troubled and full of thought, and not knowing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: what to do. And while he pondered and studied, several days went by and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the 14th of February was come. Then Joan went to the castle and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "In God's name, Robert de Baudricourt, you are too slow about sending
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: me, and have caused damage thereby, for this day the Dauphin's cause has
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lost a battle near Orleans, and will suffer yet greater injury if you do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not send me to him soon."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The governor was perplexed by this speech, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "To-day, child, to-day? How can you know what has happened in that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: region to-day? It would take eight or ten days for the word to come."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My Voices have brought the word to me, and it is true. A battle was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lost to-day, and you are in fault to delay me so."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The governor walked the floor awhile, talking within himself, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: letting a great oath fall outside now and then; and finally he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Harkye! go in peace, and wait. If it shall turn out as you say, I will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: give you the letter and send you to the King, and not otherwise."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan said with fervor:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now God be thanked, these waiting days are almost done. In nine days
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you will fetch me the letter."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Already the people of Vaucouleurs had given her a horse and had armed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and equipped her as a soldier. She got no chance to try the horse and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: see if she could ride it, for her great first duty was to abide at her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: post and lift up the hopes and spirits of all who would come to talk
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with her, and prepare them to help in the rescue and regeneration of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the kingdom. This occupied every waking moment she had. But it was no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: matter. There was nothing she could not learn--and in the briefest time,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: too. Her horse would find this out in the first hour. Meantime the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: brothers and I took the horse in turn and began to learn to ride. And we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had teaching in the use of the sword and other arms also.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: On the 20th Joan called her small army together--the two knights and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her two brothers and me--for a private council of war. No, it was not a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: council, that is not the right name, for she did not consult with us,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she merely gave us orders. She mapped out the course she would travel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: toward the King, and did it like a person perfectly versed in geography;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and this itinerary of daily marches was so arranged as to avoid here and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there peculiarly dangerous regions by flank movements--which showed that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she knew her political geography as intimately as she knew her physical
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: geography; yet she had never had a day's schooling, of course, and was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: without education. I was astonished, but thought her Voices must have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: taught her. But upon reflection I saw that this was not so. By her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: references to what this and that and the other person had told her,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I perceived that she had been diligently questioning those crowds of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: visiting strangers, and that out of them she had patiently dug all this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mass of invaluable knowledge. The two knights were filled with wonder at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her good sense and sagacity.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She commanded us to make preparations to travel by night and sleep by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: day in concealment, as almost the whole of our long journey would be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: through the enemy's country.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Also, she commanded that we should keep the date of our departure a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: secret, since she meant to get away unobserved. Otherwise we should
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: be sent off with a grand demonstration which would advertise us to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enemy, and we should be ambushed and captured somewhere. Finally she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Nothing remains, now, but that I confide to you the date of our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: departure, so that you may make all needful preparation in time, leaving
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nothing to be done in haste and badly at the last moment. We march the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: 23d, at eleven of the clock at night."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then we were dismissed. The two knights were startled--yes, and troubled;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the Sieur Bertrand said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Even if the governor shall really furnish the letter and the escort,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he still may not do it in time to meet the date she has chosen. Then how
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: can she venture to name that date? It is a great risk--a great risk to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: select and decide upon the date, in this state of uncertainty."

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He got no further, for she interrupted him, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 3 The Paladin Groans and Boasts
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: WE WERE twenty-five strong, and well equipped. We rode in double file,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan and her brothers in the center of the column, with Jean de Metz
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: at the head of it and the Sieur Bertrand at its extreme rear. In two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: or three hours we should be in the enemy's country, and then none
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would venture to desert. By and by we began to hear groans and sobs and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: execrations from different points along the line, and upon inquiry found
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that six of our men were peasants who had never ridden a horse before,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and were finding it very difficult to stay in their saddles, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: moreover were now beginning to suffer considerable bodily torture. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had been seized by the governor at the last moment and pressed into the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: service to make up the tale, and he had placed a veteran alongside of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: each with orders to help him stick to the saddle, and kill him if he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tried to desert.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: These poor devils had kept quiet as long as they could, but their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: physical miseries were become so sharp by this time that they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: obliged to give them vent. But we were within the enemy's country now,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: so there was no help for them, they must continue the march, though
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan said that if they chose to take the risk they might depart.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They preferred to stay with us. We modified our pace now, and moved
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cautiously, and the new men were warned to keep their sorrows to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: themselves and not get the command into danger with their curses and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lamentations.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were sound asleep in spite of the cold ground and the frosty air.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I woke at noon out of such a solid and stupefying sleep that at first my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wits were all astray, and I did not know where I was nor what had been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: happening. Then my senses cleared, and I remembered. As I lay there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thinking over the strange events of the past month or two the thought
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: came into my mind, greatly surprising me, that one of Joan's prophecies
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had failed; for where were Noel and the Paladin, who were to join us at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the eleventh hour? By this time, you see, I had gotten used to expecting
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: everything Joan said to come true. So, being disturbed and troubled by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: these thoughts, I opened my eyes. Well, there stood the Paladin leaning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: against a tree and looking down on me! How often that happens; you think
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of a person, or speak of a person, and there he stands before you, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you not dreaming he is near. It looks as if his being near is really the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thing that makes you think of him, and not just an accident, as people
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: imagine. Well, be that as it may, there was the Paladin, anyway, looking
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: down in my face and waiting for me to wake. I was ever so glad to see
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from the camp--he limping like a cripple--and told him to sit down, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now, where have you dropped down from? And how did you happen to light
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in this place? And what do the soldier-clothes mean? Tell me all about
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He answered:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I marched with you last night."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No!" (To myself I said, "The prophecy has not all failed--half of it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: has come true.") "Yes, I did. I hurried up from Domremy to join, and was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: allowed me to come."

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: in times like these."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: in the clouds when the storm calls it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: That pleased him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: will make yourself conspicuous."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: He was charmed with this speech, and it swelled him up like a bladder.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: world, I should say--to raise the fame of a private soldier above theirs,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: and extinguish the glory of their names with its shadow."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
