title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: An odor as of breakfast came stealing through the wood; the Paladin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: unconsciously inflated his nostrils in lustful response, and got up and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: limped painfully away, saying he must go and look to his horse.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At bottom he was all right and a good-hearted giant, without any harm
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in him, for it is no harm to bark, if one stops there and does not bite,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and it is no harm to be an ass, if one is content to bray and not kick.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: If this vast structure of brawn and muscle and vanity and foolishness
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seemed to have a libelous tongue, what of it? There was no malice behind
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it; and besides, the defect was not of his own creation; it was the work
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Noel Rainguesson, who had nurtured it, fostered it, built it up and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: perfected it, for the entertainment he got out of it. His careless light
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: heart had to have somebody to nag and chaff and make fun of, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Paladin had only needed development in order to meet its requirements,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: consequently the development was taken in hand and diligently attended
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to and looked after, gnat-and-bull fashion, for years, to the neglect
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and damage of far more important concerns. The result was an unqualified
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: success. Noel prized the society of the Paladin above everybody else's;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Paladin preferred anybody's to Noel's. The big fellow was often seen
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with the little fellow, but it was for the same reason that the bull is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: often seen with the gnat.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: With the first opportunity, I had a talk with Noel. I welcomed him to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: our expedition, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It was fine and brave of you to volunteer, Noel."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: His eye twinkled, and he answered:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, it was rather fine, I think. Still, the credit doesn't all belong
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to me; I had help."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Who helped you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The governor."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "How?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, I'll tell you the whole thing. I came up from Domremy to see the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crowds and the general show, for I hadn't ever had any experience of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: such things, of course, and this was a great opportunity; but I hadn't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: any mind to volunteer. I overtook the Paladin on the road and let him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have my company the rest of the way, although he did not want it and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said so; and while we were gawking and blinking in the glare of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: governor's torches they seized us and four more and added us to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: escort, and that is really how I came to volunteer. But, after all, I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wasn't sorry, remembering how dull life would have been in the village
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: without the Paladin."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "How did he feel about it? Was he satisfied?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I think he was glad."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Why?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Because he said he wasn't. He was taken by surprise, you see, and it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not likely that he could tell the truth without preparation. Not that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he would have prepared, if he had had the chance, for I do not think he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would. I am not charging him with that. In the same space of time that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he could prepare to speak the truth, he could also prepare to lie;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: besides, his judgment would be cool then, and would warn him against
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fooling with new methods in an emergency. No, I am sure he was glad,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: because he said he wasn't."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Do you think he was very glad?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, I know he was. He begged like a slave, and bawled for his mother.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He said his health was delicate, and he didn't know how to ride a horse,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and he knew he couldn't outlive the first march. But really he wasn't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: looking as delicate as he was feeling. There was a cask of wine there,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a proper lift for four men. The governor's temper got afire, and he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: delivered an oath at him that knocked up the dust where it struck the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ground, and told him to shoulder that cask or he would carve him to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cutlets and send him home in a basket. The Paladin did it, and that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: secured his promotion to a privacy in the escort without any further
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: debate."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, you seem to make it quite plain that he was glad to join--that is,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: if your premises are right that you start from. How did he stand the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: march last night?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "About as I did. If he made the more noise, it was the privilege of his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bulk. We stayed in our saddles because we had help. We are equally lame
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to-day, and if he likes to sit down, let him; I prefer to stand."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 4 Joan Leads Us Through the Enemy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: WE WERE called to quarters and subjected to a searching inspection by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan. Then she made a short little talk in which she said that even the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rude business of war could be conducted better without profanity and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other brutalities of speech than with them, and that she should strictly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: require us to remember and apply this admonition. She ordered half an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hour's horsemanship drill for the novices then, and appointed one of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: veterans to conduct it. It was a ridiculous exhibition, but we learned
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: something, and Joan was satisfied and complimented us. She did not take
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: any instruction herself or go through the evolutions and manoeuvres, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: merely sat her horse like a martial little statue and looked on. That
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was sufficient for her, you see. She would not miss or forget a detail
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the lesson, she would take it all in with her eye and her mind, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: apply it afterward with as much certainty and confidence as if she had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: already practised it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We now made three night marches of twelve or thirteen leagues each,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: riding in peace and undisturbed, being taken for a roving band of Free
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Companions. Country-folk were glad to have that sort of people go
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by without stopping. Still, they were very wearying marches, and not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: comfortable, for the bridges were few and the streams many, and as we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had to ford them we found the water dismally cold, and afterward had to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bed ourselves, still wet, on the frosty or snowy ground, and get warm
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as we might and sleep if we could, for it would not have been prudent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to build fires. Our energies languished under these hardships and deadly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fatigues, but Joan's did not. Her step kept its spring and firmness and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her eye its fire. We could only wonder at this, we could not explain it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But if we had had hard times before, I know not what to call the five
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nights that now followed, for the marches were as fatiguing, the baths
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as cold, and we were ambuscaded seven times in addition, and lost two
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: novices and three veterans in the resulting fights. The news had leaked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out and gone abroad that the inspired Virgin of Vaucouleurs was making
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for the King with an escort, and all the roads were being watched now.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: These five nights disheartened the command a good deal. This was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: aggravated by a discovery which Noel made, and which he promptly made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: known at headquarters. Some of the men had been trying to understand why
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan continued to be alert, vigorous, and confident while the strongest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: men in the company were fagged with the heavy marches and exposure and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were become morose and irritable. There, it shows you how men can have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eyes and yet not see. All their lives those men had seen their own
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: women-folks hitched up with a cow and dragging the plow in the fields
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: while the men did the driving. They had also seen other evidences that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: women have far more endurance and patience and fortitude than men--but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: what good had their seeing these things been to them? None. It had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: taught them nothing. They were still surprised to see a girl of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seventeen bear the fatigues of war better than trained veterans of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: army. Moreover, they did not reflect that a great soul, with a great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: purpose, can make a weak body strong and keep it so; and here was the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: greatest soul in the universe; but how could they know that, those dumb
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: creatures? No, they knew nothing, and their reasonings were of a piece
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with their ignorance. They argued and discussed among themselves, with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Noel listening, and arrived at the decision that Joan was a witch, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had her strange pluck and strength from Satan; so they made a plan to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: watch for a safe opportunity to take her life.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To have secret plottings of this sort going on in our midst was a very
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: serious business, of course, and the knights asked Joan's permission to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hang the plotters, but she refused without hesitancy. She said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Neither these men nor any others can take my life before my mission is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: accomplished, therefore why should I have their blood upon my hands? I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will inform them of this, and also admonish them. Call them before me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When they came she made that statement to them in a plain matter-of-fact
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: way, and just as if the thought never entered her mind that any one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: could doubt it after she had given her word that it was true. The men
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were evidently amazed and impressed to hear her say such a thing in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: such a sure and confident way, for prophecies boldly uttered never fall
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: barren on superstitious ears. Yes, this speech certainly impressed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them, but her closing remark impressed them still more. It was for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ringleader, and Joan said it sorrowfully:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is a pity that you should plot another's death when your own is so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: close at hand."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: That man's horse stumbled and fell on him in the first ford which we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crossed that night, and he was drowned before we could help him. We had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: no more conspiracies.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This night was harassed with ambuscades, but we got through without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: having any men killed. One more night would carry us over the hostile
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: frontier if we had good luck, and we saw the night close down with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a good deal of solicitude. Always before, we had been more or less
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: reluctant to start out into the gloom and the silence to be frozen in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the fords and persecuted by the enemy, but this time we were impatient
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to get under way and have it over, although there was promise of more
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and harder fighting than any of the previous nights had furnished.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Moreover, in front of us about three leagues there was a deep stream
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with a frail wooden bridge over it, and as a cold rain mixed with snow
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had been falling steadily all day we were anxious to find out whether we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were in a trap or not. If the swollen stream had washed away the bridge,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we might properly consider ourselves trapped and cut off from escape.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: As soon as it was dark we filed out from the depth of the forest where
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we had been hidden and began the march. From the time that we had begun
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to encounter ambushes Joan had ridden at the head of the column, and she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: took this post now. By the time we had gone a league the rain and snow
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had turned to sleet, and under the impulse of the storm-wind it lashed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: my face like whips, and I envied Joan and the knights, who could close
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their visors and shut up their heads in their helmets as in a box. Now,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out of the pitchy darkness and close at hand, came the sharp command:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Halt!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We obeyed. I made out a dim mass in front of us which might be a body of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: horsemen, but one could not be sure. A man rode up and said to Joan in a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tone of reproof:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, you have taken your time, truly. And what have you found out? Is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she still behind us, or in front?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan answered in a level voice:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "She is still behind."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This news softened the stranger's tone. He said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If you know that to be true, you have not lost your time, Captain. But
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: are you sure? How do you know?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Because I have seen her."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Seen her! Seen the Virgin herself?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, I have been in her camp."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Is it possible! Captain Raymond, I ask you to pardon me for speaking in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that tone just now. You have performed a daring and admirable service.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Where was she camped?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "In the forest, not more than a league from here."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Good! I was afraid we might be still behind her, but now that we know
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she is behind us, everything is safe. She is our game. We will hang her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: You shall hang her yourself. No one has so well earned the privilege of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: abolishing this pestilent limb of Satan."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I do not know how to thank you sufficiently. If we catch her, I--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If! I will take care of that; give yourself no uneasiness. All I want
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is just a look at her, to see what the imp is like that has been able to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: make all this noise, then you and the halter may have her. How many men
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: has she?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I counted but eighteen, but she may have had two or three pickets out."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Is that all? It won't be a mouthful for my force. Is it true that she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is only a girl?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes; she is not more than seventeen."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It passes belief! Is she robust, or slender?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Slender."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The officer pondered a moment or two, then he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Was she preparing to break camp?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Not when I had my last glimpse of her."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What was she doing?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "She was talking quietly with an officer."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Quietly? Not giving orders?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No, talking as quietly as we are now."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That is good. She is feeling a false security. She would have been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: restless and fussy else--it is the way of her sex when danger is about.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: As she was making no preparation to break camp--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "She certainly was not when I saw her last."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "--and was chatting quietly and at her ease, it means that this weather
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is not to her taste. Night-marching in sleet and wind is not for chits
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of seventeen. No; she will stay where she is. She has my thanks. We will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: camp, ourselves; here is as good a place as any. Let us get about it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If you command it--certainly. But she has two knights with her. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: might force her to march, particularly if the weather should improve."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was scared, and impatient to be getting out of this peril, and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: distressed and worried me to have Joan apparently set herself to work
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to make delay and increase the danger--still, I thought she probably knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: better than I what to do. The officer said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, in that case we are here to block the way."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, if they come this way. But if they should send out spies, and find
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out enough to make them want to try for the bridge through the woods? Is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it best to allow the bridge to stand?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It made me shiver to hear her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The officer considered awhile, then said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It might be well enough to send a force to destroy the bridge. I was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: intending to occupy it with the whole command, but that is not necessary
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: now."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan said, tranquilly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "With your permission, I will go and destroy it myself."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Ah, now I saw her idea, and was glad she had had the cleverness to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: invent it and the ability to keep her head cool and think of it in that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tight place. The officer replied:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You have it, Captain, and my thanks. With you to do it, it will be well
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: done; I could send another in your place, but not a better."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They saluted, and we moved forward. I breathed freer. A dozen times I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had imagined I heard the hoofbeats of the real Captain Raymond's troop
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: arriving behind us, and had been sitting on pins and needles all the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: while that that conversation was dragging along. I breathed freer, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was still not comfortable, for Joan had given only the simple command,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Forward!" Consequently we moved in a walk. Moved in a dead walk past
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a dim and lengthening column of enemies at our side. The suspense was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: exhausting, yet it lasted but a short while, for when the enemy's bugles
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sang the "Dismount!" Joan gave the word to trot, and that was a great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: relief to me. She was always at herself, you see. Before the command
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to dismount had been given, somebody might have wanted the countersign
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: somewhere along that line if we came flying by at speed, but now we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seemed to be on our way to our allotted camping position, so we were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: allowed to pass unchallenged. The further we went the more formidable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was the strength revealed by the hostile force. Perhaps it was only a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hundred or two, but to me it seemed a thousand. When we passed the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: last of these people I was thankful, and the deeper we plowed into the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: darkness beyond them the better I felt. I came nearer and nearer to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: feeling good, for an hour; then we found the bridge still standing,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and I felt entirely good. We crossed it and destroyed it, and then I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: felt--but I cannot describe what I felt. One has to feel it himself in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: order to know what it is like.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We had expected to hear the rush of a pursuing force behind us, for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we thought that the real Captain Raymond would arrive and suggest that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: perhaps the troop that had been mistaken for his belonged to the Virgin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Vaucouleurs; but he must have been delayed seriously, for when we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: resumed our march beyond the river there were no sounds behind us except
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: those which the storm was furnishing.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I said that Joan had harvested a good many compliments intended for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Captain Raymond, and that he would find nothing of a crop left but a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dry stubble of reprimands when he got back, and a commander just in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: humor to superintend the gathering of it in.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It will be as you say, no doubt; for the commander took a troop for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: granted, in the night and unchallenged, and would have camped without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sending a force to destroy the bridge if he had been left unadvised,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and none are so ready to find fault with others as those who do things
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: worthy of blame themselves."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Sieur Bertrand was amused at Joan's naive way of referring to her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: advice as if it had been a valuable present to a hostile leader who was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: saved by it from making a censurable blunder of omission, and then he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: went on to admire how ingeniously she had deceived that man and yet had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not told him anything that was not the truth. This troubled Joan, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I thought he was deceiving himself. I forbore to tell him lies, for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that would have been wrong; but if my truths deceived him, perhaps that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: made them lies, and I am to blame. I would God I knew if I have done
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wrong."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was assured that she had done right, and that in the perils and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: necessities of war deceptions that help one's own cause and hurt the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enemy's were always permissible; but she was not quite satisfied with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that, and thought that even when a great cause was in danger one ought
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to have the privilege of trying honorable ways first. Jean said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, you told us yourself that you were going to Uncle Laxart's to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nurse his wife, but you didn't say you were going further, yet you did
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: go on to Vaucouleurs. There!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I see now," said Joan, sorrowfully. "I told no lie, yet I deceived. I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had tried all other ways first, but I could not get away, and I had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to get away. My mission required it. I did wrong, I think, and am to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: blame."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was silent a moment, turning the matter over in her mind, then she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: added, with quiet decision, "But the thing itself was right, and I would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: do it again."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It seemed an over-nice distinction, but nobody said anything. If we had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: known her as well as she knew herself, and as her later history revealed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her to us, we should have perceived that she had a clear meaning there,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and that her position was not identical with ours, as we were supposing,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but occupied a higher plane. She would sacrifice herself--and her best
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: self; that is, her truthfulness--to save her cause; but only that; she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would not buy her life at that cost; whereas our war-ethics permitted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the purchase of our lives, or any mere military advantage, small or
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: great, by deception. Her saying seemed a commonplace at the time, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: essence of its meaning escaping us; but one sees now that it contained a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: principle which lifted it above that and made it great and fine.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Presently the wind died down, the sleet stopped falling, and the cold
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was less severe. The road was become a bog, and the horses labored
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: through it at a walk--they could do no better. As the heavy time wore
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: on, exhaustion overcame us, and we slept in our saddles. Not even the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dangers that threatened us could keep us awake.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This tenth night seemed longer than any of the others, and of course
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was the hardest, because we had been accumulating fatigue from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: beginning, and had more of it on hand now than at any previous time.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But we were not molested again. When the dull dawn came at last we saw
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a river before us and we knew it was the Loire; we entered the town of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Gien, and knew we were in a friendly land, with the hostiles all behind
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: us. That was a glad morning for us.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We were a worn and bedraggled and shabby-looking troop; and still, as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always, Joan was the freshest of us all, in both body and spirits. We
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had averaged above thirteen leagues a night, by tortuous and wretched
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: roads. It was a remarkable march, and shows what men can do when they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have a leader with a determined purpose and a resolution that never
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flags.

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: WE RESTED and otherwise refreshed ourselves two or three hours at Gien,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but by that time the news was abroad that the young girl commissioned
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of God to deliver France was come; wherefore, such a press of people
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flocked to our quarters to get sight of her that it seemed best to seek
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a quieter place; so we pushed on and halted at a small village called
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Fierbois.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We were now within six leagues of the King, who was at the Castle of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chinon. Joan dictated a letter to him at once, and I wrote it. In it she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said she had come a hundred and fifty leagues to bring him good news,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and begged the privilege of delivering it in person. She added that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: although she had never seen him she would know him in any disguise and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would point him out.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all the afternoon, and after supper we felt pretty fresh and fine,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tap-room of the village inn to ourselves, and for the first time in ten
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and fatiguing labors. The Paladin was suddenly become his ancient
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: self again, and was swaggering up and down, a very monument of

text: self-complacency. Noel Rainguesson said:

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I think it is wonderful, the way he has brought us through."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Who?" asked Jean.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Why, the Paladin."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Everything. It was nothing but Joan's confidence in his discretion that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enabled her to keep up her heart. She could depend on us and on herself
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for valor, but discretion is the winning thing in war, after all;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: discretion is the rarest and loftiest of qualities, and he has got more
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of it than any other man in France--more of it, perhaps, than any other
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sixty men in France."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now you are getting ready to make a fool of yourself, Noel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tongue of yours around your neck and stick the end of it in your ear,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: then you'll be the less likely to get into trouble."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I didn't know he had more discretion than other people," said Pierre,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "for discretion argues brains, and he hasn't any more brains than the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rest of us, in my opinion."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No, you are wrong there. Discretion hasn't anything to do with brains;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: brains are an obstruction to it, for it does not reason, it feels.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Perfect discretion means absence of brains. Discretion is a quality
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the heart--solely a quality of the heart; it acts upon us through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: feeling. We know this because if it were an intellectual quality it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would only perceive a danger, for instance, where a danger exists;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: whereas--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "--whereas, it being purely a quality of the heart, and proceeding by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: feeling, not reason, its reach is correspondingly wider and sublimer,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all; as, for instance, that night in the fog, when the Paladin took his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It's a lie! a lie without shadow of foundation, and I call upon you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all to beware you give credence to the malicious inventions of this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: if it isn't so--and whoever wants to believe it can, and whoever don't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: can let it alone."

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: temperately, but always flies off the handle and becomes disagreeable.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: front."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: these infamies. I can endure your lies, but not your love. Keep that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: glimpse of the Maid.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: It has been said that misfortunes never come one at a time, but in a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: body. In our case it was the same with good luck. Having got a start, it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: came flooding in, tide after tide. Our next wave of it was of this sort.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: There had been grave doubts among the priests as to whether the Church
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ought to permit a female soldier to dress like a man. But now came a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the time--one of whom had been Chancellor of the University of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Paris--rendered it. They decided that since Joan "must do the work of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a man and a soldier, it is just and legitimate that her apparel should
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: conform to the situation."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was a great point gained, the Church's authority to dress as a man.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Oh, yes, wave on wave the good luck came sweeping in. Never mind about
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: swept us small fry quite off our feet and almost drowned us with joy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with it, and the next morning bright and early the clear notes of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
