text: and before he could begin again, one of D'Aulon's liveried servants
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: appeared and said we were required at headquarters. We rose, and Noel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There--what did I tell you? I have a presentiment--the spirit of prophecy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is upon me. She is going to appoint him, and we are to go there and do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him homage. Come along!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But the Paladin was afraid to go, so we left him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When we presently stood in the presence, in front of a crowd of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: glittering officers of the army, Joan greeted us with a winning smile,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and said she appointed all of us to places in her household, for she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wanted her old friends by her. It was a beautiful surprise to have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ourselves honored like this when she could have had people of birth and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: consequence instead, but we couldn't find our tongues to say so, she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was become so great and so high above us now. One at a time we stepped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forward and each received his warrant from the hand of our chief,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: D'Aulon. All of us had honorable places; the two knights stood highest;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: then Joan's two brothers; I was first page and secretary, a young
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: gentleman named Raimond was second page; Noel was her messenger; she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had two heralds, and also a chaplain and almoner, whose name was Jean
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Pasquerel. She had previously appointed a maitre d'hotel and a number of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: domestics. Now she looked around and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But where is the Paladin?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Sieur Bertrand said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "He thought he was not sent for, your Excellency."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now that is not well. Let him be called."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Paladin entered humbly enough. He ventured no farther than just
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: within the door. He stopped there, looking embarrassed and afraid. Then
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan spoke pleasantly, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I watched you on the road. You began badly, but improved. Of old you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were a fantastic talker, but there is a man in you, and I will bring it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out." It was fine to see the Paladin's face light up when she said that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Will you follow where I lead?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Into the fire!" he said; and I said to myself, "By the ring of that,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I think she has turned this braggart into a hero. It is another of her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: miracles, I make no doubt of it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I believe you," said Joan. "Here--take my banner. You will ride with me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in every field, and when France is saved, you will give it me back."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He took the banner, which is now the most precious of the memorials that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: remain of Joan of Arc, and his voice was unsteady with emotion when he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If I ever disgrace this trust, my comrades here will know how to do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a friend's office upon my body, and this charge I lay upon them, as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: knowing they will not fail me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 11 The War March Is Begun
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: NOEL and I went back together--silent at first, and impressed.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Finally Noel came up out of his thinkings and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The first shall be last and the last first--there's authority for this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: surprise. But at the same time wasn't it a lofty hoist for our big
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bull!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It truly was; I am not over being stunned yet. It was the greatest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: place in her gift."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, it was. There are many generals, and she can create more; but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there is only one Standard-Bearer."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "True. It is the most conspicuous place in the army, after her own."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And the most coveted and honorable. Sons of two dukes tried to get
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it, as we know. And of all people in the world, this majestic windmill
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: carries it off. Well, isn't it a gigantic promotion, when you come to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: look at it!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There's no doubt about it. It's a kind of copy of Joan's own in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: miniature."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I don't know how to account for it--do you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes--without any trouble at all--that is, I think I do."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Noel was surprised at that, and glanced up quickly, as if to see if I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was in earnest. He said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I thought you couldn't be in earnest, but I see you are. If you can
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: make me understand this puzzle, do it. Tell me what the explanation is."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I believe I can. You have noticed that our chief knight says a good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: many wise things and has a thoughtful head on his shoulders. One day,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: riding along, we were talking about Joan's great talents, and he said,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: 'But, greatest of all her gifts, she has the seeing eye.' I said, like
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: an unthinking fool, 'The seeing eye?--I shouldn't count on that for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: much--I suppose we all have it.' 'No,' he said; 'very few have it.' Then
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he explained, and made his meaning clear. He said the common eye sees
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: only the outside of things, and judges by that, but the seeing eye
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pierces through and reads the heart and the soul, finding there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: capacities which the outside didn't indicate or promise, and which the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other kind of eye couldn't detect. He said the mightiest military genius
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: must fail and come to nothing if it have not the seeing eye--that is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to say, if it cannot read men and select its subordinates with an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: infallible judgment. It sees as by intuition that this man is good for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: strategy, that one for dash and daredevil assault, the other for patient
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bulldog persistence, and it appoints each to his right place and wins,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: while the commander without the seeing eye would give to each the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other's place and lose. He was right about Joan, and I saw it. When she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was a child and the tramp came one night, her father and all of us took
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him for a rascal, but she saw the honest man through the rags. When I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dined with the governor of Vaucouleurs so long ago, I saw nothing in our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: two knights, though I sat with them and talked with them two hours;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was there five minutes, and neither spoke with them nor heard them
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: speak, yet she marked them for men of worth and fidelity, and they have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: confirmed her judgment. Whom has she sent for to take charge of this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thundering rabble of new recruits at Blois, made up of old disbanded
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Armagnac raiders, unspeakable hellions, every one? Why, she has sent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for Satan himself--that is to say, La Hire--that military hurricane,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that godless swashbuckler, that lurid conflagration of blasphemy, that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Vesuvius of profanity, forever in eruption. Does he know how to deal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with that mob of roaring devils? Better than any man that lives; for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he is the head devil of this world his own self, he is the match of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: whole of them combined, and probably the father of most of them. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: places him in temporary command until she can get to Blois herself--and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: then! Why, then she will certainly take them in hand personally, or I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: don't know her as well as I ought to, after all these years of intimacy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: That will be a sight to see--that fair spirit in her white armor,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: delivering her will to that muck-heap, that rag-pile, that abandoned
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: refuse of perdition."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "La Hire!" cried Noel, "our hero of all these years--I do want to see
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that man!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I too. His name stirs me just as it did when I was a little boy."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I want to hear him swear."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Of course, I would rather hear him swear than another man pray. He is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the frankest man there is, and the naivest. Once when he was rebuked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for pillaging on his raids, he said it was nothing. Said he, 'If God
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Father were a soldier, He would rob.' I judge he is the right man to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: take temporary charge there at Blois. Joan has cast the seeing eye upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him, you see."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Which brings us back to where we started. I have an honest affection
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for the Paladin, and not merely because he is a good fellow, but because
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he is my child--I made him what he is, the windiest blusterer and most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: catholic liar in the kingdom. I'm glad of his luck, but I hadn't the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seeing eye. I shouldn't have chosen him for the most dangerous post in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the army. I should have placed him in the rear to kill the wounded and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: violate the dead."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, we shall see. Joan probably knows what is in him better than
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we do. And I'll give you another idea. When a person in Joan of Arc's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: position tells a man he is brave, he believes it; and believing it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enough; in fact, to believe yourself brave is to be brave; it is the one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: only essential thing."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now you've hit it!" cried Noel. "She's got the creating mouth as well
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as the seeing eye! Ah, yes, that is the thing. France was cowed and a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: coward; Joan of Arc has spoken, and France is marching, with her head
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: up!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was summoned now to write a letter from Joan's dictation. During the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: next day and night our several uniforms were made by the tailors, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: our new armor provided. We were beautiful to look upon now, whether
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: clothed for peace or war. Clothed for peace, in costly stuffs and rich
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: colors, the Paladin was a tower dyed with the glories of the sunset;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: plumed and sashed and iron-clad for war, he was a still statelier thing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to look at.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Orders had been issued for the march toward Blois. It was a clear,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sharp, beautiful morning. As our showy great company trotted out in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: column, riding two and two, Joan and the Duke of Alencon in the lead,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: D'Aulon and the big standard-bearer next, and so on, we made a handsome
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: spectacle, as you may well imagine; and as we plowed through the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cheering crowds, with Joan bowing her plumed head to left and right and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the sun glinting from her silver mail, the spectators realized that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the curtain was rolling up before their eyes upon the first act of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: prodigious drama, and their rising hopes were expressed in an enthusiasm
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that increased with each moment, until at last one seemed to even
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: physically feel the concussion of the huzzas as well as hear them. Far
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: down the street we heard the softened strains of wind-blown music, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: saw a cloud of lancers moving, the sun glowing with a subdued light upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the massed armor, but striking bright upon the soaring lance-heads--a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: vaguely luminous nebula, so to speak, with a constellation twinkling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: above it--and that was our guard of honor. It joined us, the procession
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was complete, the first war-march of Joan of Arc was begun, the curtain
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was up.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 12 Joan Puts Heart in Her Army
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: WE WERE at Blois three days. Oh, that camp, it is one of the treasures
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of my memory! Order? There was no more order among those brigands than
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there is among the wolves and the hyenas. They went roaring and drinking
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about, whooping, shouting, swearing, and entertaining themselves with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all manner of rude and riotous horse-play; and the place was full of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: loud and lewd women, and they were no whit behind the men for romps and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: noise and fantastics.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was in the midst of this wild mob that Noel and I had our first
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: glimpse of La Hire. He answered to our dearest dreams. He was of great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: size and of martial bearing, he was cased in mail from head to heel,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with a bushel of swishing plumes on his helmet, and at his side the vast
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sword of the time.

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: through the camp he was restoring order, and proclaiming that the Maid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had come, and he would have no such spectacle as this exposed to the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: head of the army. His way of creating order was his own, not borrowed.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He did it with his great fists. As he moved along swearing and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: admonishing, he let drive this way, that way, and the other, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wherever his blow landed, a man went down.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Damn you!" he said, "staggering and cursing around like this, and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flat. What his idea of straightening up was, was his own secret.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: We followed the veteran to headquarters, listening, observing,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: admiring--yes, devouring, you may say, the pet hero of the boys of France
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from our cradles up to that happy day, and their idol and ours. I called
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to mind how Joan had once rebuked the Paladin, there in the pastures
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Domremy, for uttering lightly those mighty names, La Hire and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bastard of Orleans, and how she said that if she could but be permitted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to stand afar off and let her eyes rest once upon those great men, she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would hold it a privilege. They were to her and the other girls just
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: what they were to the boys. Well, here was one of them at last--and what
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was his errand? It was hard to realize it, and yet it was true; he was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: coming to uncover his head before her and take her orders.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: While he was quieting a considerable group of his brigands in his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soothing way, near headquarters, we stepped on ahead and got a glimpse
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of Joan's military family, the great chiefs of the army, for they had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: men in beautiful armor, but the Lord High Admiral of France was the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When La Hire entered, one could see the surprise in his face at Joan's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: beauty and extreme youth, and one could see, too, by Joan's glad smile,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: last. La Hire bowed low, with his helmet in his gauntleted hand, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: made a bluff but handsome little speech with hardly an oath in it, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: The visit of ceremony was soon over, and the others went away; but La
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Hire stayed, and he and Joan sat there, and he sipped her wine, and they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: breath stand still. For, to begin with, she said that all those loose
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to remain. Next, the rough carousing must stop, drinking must be brought
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: within proper and strictly defined limits, and discipline must take the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: place of disorder. And finally she climaxed the list of surprises with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this--which nearly lifted him out of his armor:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: absolve himself from sin; and all accepted recruits must be present at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: La Hire could not say a word for a good part of a minute, then he said,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in deep dejection:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, sweet child, they were littered in hell, these poor darlings of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mine! Attend mass? Why, dear heart, they'll see us both damned first!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And he went on, pouring out a most pathetic stream of arguments and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: blasphemy, which broke Joan all up, and made her laugh as she had not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But she stuck to her point; so the soldier yielded, and said all right,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: if such were the orders he must obey, and would do the best that was in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him; then he refreshed himself with a lurid explosion of oaths, and said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: life, he would knock his head off. That started Joan off again; she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: form of conversions. She said they must be voluntary.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: La Hire said that that was all right, he wasn't going to kill the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: voluntary ones, but only the others.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: No matter, none of them must be killed--Joan couldn't have it. She said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I? Impossible! Oh, this is lunacy!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, no, it isn't. You are going to the service--twice a day."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, am I dreaming? Am I drunk--or is my hearing playing me false? Why, I

text: would rather go to--"

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it will come easy. Now don't look downhearted like that. Soon you won't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: mind it."

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

text: and down that camp, and wherever that fair young form appeared in its

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: of a man--sinful by nature and habit, but full of superstitious respect

text: for holy places.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the hot desire she had aroused in it to be led against the enemy,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: gates of hell with it now."

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan and he were inseparable, and a quaint and pleasant contrast they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: made. He was so big, she so little; he was so gray and so far along in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his pilgrimage of life, she so youthful; his face was so bronzed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and scarred, hers so fair and pink, so fresh and smooth; she was so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cyclopedia of sin. In her eye was stored all charity and compassion,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: All the three days that we were in Blois, Joan worked earnestly and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tirelessly to bring La Hire to God--to rescue him from the bondage of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sin--to breathe into his stormy heart the serenity and peace of religion.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: days of our stay, begging about piteously to be let off--to be let off
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from just that one thing, that impossible thing; he would do anything
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: else--anything--command, and he would obey--he would go through the fire

author: Twain, Mark

text: for her if she said the word--but spare him this, only this, for he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: couldn't pray, had never prayed, he was ignorant of how to frame a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: prayer, he had no words to put it in.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: (1) This prayer has been stolen many times and by many nations in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: past four hundred and sixty years, but it originated with La Hire, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the fact is of official record in the National Archives of France. We
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have the authority of Michelet for this.--TRANSLATOR

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 13 Checked by the Folly of the Wise
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: WE MARCHED out in great strength and splendor, and took the road toward
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Orleans. The initial part of Joan's great dream was realizing itself at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: last. It was the first time that any of us youngsters had ever seen an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: army, and it was a most stately and imposing spectacle to us. It was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: indeed an inspiring sight, that interminable column, stretching
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: away into the fading distances, and curving itself in and out of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crookedness of the road like a mighty serpent. Joan rode at the head of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it with her personal staff; then came a body of priests singing the Veni
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Creator, the banner of the Cross rising out of their midst; after these
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the glinting forest of spears. The several divisions were commanded by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the great Armagnac generals, La Hire, and Marshal de Boussac, the Sire
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: de Retz, Florent d'Illiers, and Poton de Saintrailles.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Each in his degree was tough, and there were three degrees--tough,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tougher, toughest--and La Hire was the last by a shade, but only a shade.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They were just illustrious official brigands, the whole party; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by long habits of lawlessness they had lost all acquaintanceship with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: obedience, if they had ever had any.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But what was the good of saying that? These independent birds knew no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: law. They seldom obeyed the King; they never obeyed him when it didn't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: suit them to do it. Would they obey the Maid? In the first place they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wouldn't know how to obey her or anybody else, and in the second place
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was of course not possible for them to take her military character
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seriously--that country-girl of seventeen who had been trained for the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: complex and terrible business of war--how? By tending sheep.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They had no idea of obeying her except in cases where their veteran
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: military knowledge and experience showed them that the thing she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: required was sound and right when gauged by the regular military
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: standards. Were they to blame for this attitude? I should think not.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Old war-worn captains are hard-headed, practical men. They do not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: easily believe in the ability of ignorant children to plan campaigns
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and command armies. No general that ever lived could have taken Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seriously (militarily) before she raised the siege of Orleans and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: followed it with the great campaign of the Loire.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Did they consider Joan valueless? Far from it. They valued her as the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fruitful earth values the sun--they fully believed she could produce the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crop, but that it was in their line of business, not hers, to take
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it off. They had a deep and superstitious reverence for her as being
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: endowed with a mysterious supernatural something that was able to do a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mighty thing which they were powerless to do--blow the breath of life and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: valor into the dead corpses of cowed armies and turn them into heroes.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To their minds they were everything with her, but nothing without her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She could inspire the soldiers and fit them for battle--but fight
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the battle herself? Oh, nonsense--that was their function. They, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: generals, would fight the battles, Joan would give the victory. That was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their idea--an unconscious paraphrase of Joan's reply to the Dominican.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: So they began by playing a deception upon her. She had a clear idea
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of how she meant to proceed. It was her purpose to march boldly upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Orleans by the north bank of the Loire. She gave that order to her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: generals. They said to themselves, "The idea is insane--it is blunder No.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: 1; it is what might have been expected of this child who is ignorant of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: war." They privately sent the word to the Bastard of Orleans. He also
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: recognized the insanity of it--at least he thought he did--and privately
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: advised the generals to get around the order in some way.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: They did it by deceiving Joan. She trusted those people, she was not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: expecting this sort of treatment, and was not on the lookout for it. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was a lesson to her; she saw to it that the game was not played a second
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: time.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Why was Joan's idea insane, from the generals' point of view, but not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from hers? Because her plan was to raise the siege immediately, by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fighting, while theirs was to besiege the besiegers and starve them out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by closing their communications--a plan which would require months in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: consummation.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The English had built a fence of strong fortresses called bastilles
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: around Orleans--fortresses which closed all the gates of the city but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one. To the French generals the idea of trying to fight their way past
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: those fortresses and lead the army into Orleans was preposterous; they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: believed that the result would be the army's destruction. One may not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: doubt that their opinion was militarily sound--no, would have been, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for one circumstance which they overlooked. That was this: the English
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldiers were in a demoralized condition of superstitious terror; they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had become satisfied that the Maid was in league with Satan. By reason
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of this a good deal of their courage had oozed out and vanished. On the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other hand, the Maid's soldiers were full of courage, enthusiasm, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: zeal.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan could have marched by the English forts. However, it was not to be.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She had been cheated out of her first chance to strike a heavy blow for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her country.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: In camp that night she slept in her armor on the ground. It was a cold
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: night, and she was nearly as stiff as her armor itself when we resumed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the march in the morning, for iron is not good material for a blanket.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: However, her joy in being now so far on her way to the theater of her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mission was fire enough to warm her, and it soon did it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Her enthusiasm and impatience rose higher and higher with every mile
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of progress; but at last we reached Olivet, and down it went, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: indignation took its place. For she saw the trick that had been played
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon her--the river lay between us and Orleans.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was for attacking one of the three bastilles that were on our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: side of the river and forcing access to the bridge which it guarded (a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: project which, if successful, would raise the siege instantly), but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the long-ingrained fear of the English came upon her generals and they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: implored her not to make the attempt. The soldiers wanted to attack,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but had to suffer disappointment. So we moved on and came to a halt at a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: point opposite Checy, six miles above Orleans.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Dunois, Bastard of Orleans, with a body of knights and citizens, came
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: up from the city to welcome Joan. Joan was still burning with resentment
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over the trick that had been put upon her, and was not in the mood for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soft speeches, even to revered military idols of her childhood. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Are you the bastard?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, I am he, and am right glad of your coming."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And did you advise that I be brought by this side of the river instead
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of straight to Talbot and the English?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Her high manner abashed him, and he was not able to answer with anything
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: like a confident promptness, but with many hesitations and partial
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: excuses he managed to get out the confession that for what he and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: council had regarded as imperative military reasons they so advised.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "In God's name," said Joan, "my Lord's counsel is safer and wiser than
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: yours. You thought to deceive me, but you have deceived yourselves, for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I bring you the best help that ever knight or city had; for it is God's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: help, not sent for love of me, but by God's pleasure. At the prayer of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: St. Louis and St. Charlemagne He has had pity on Orleans, and will not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: suffer the enemy to have both the Duke of Orleans and his city. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: provisions to save the starving people are here, the boats are below the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: city, the wind is contrary, they cannot come up hither. Now then, tell
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: me, in God's name, you who are so wise, what that council of yours was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thinking about, to invent this foolish difficulty."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Dunois and the rest fumbled around the matter a moment, then gave in and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: conceded that a blunder had been made.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, a blunder has been made," said Joan, "and except God take your
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: proper work upon Himself and change the wind and correct your blunder
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for you, there is none else that can devise a remedy."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Some of these people began to perceive that with all her technical
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ignorance she had practical good sense, and that with all her native
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sweetness and charm she was not the right kind of a person to play with.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Presently God did take the blunder in hand, and by His grace the wind
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: did change. So the fleet of boats came up and went away loaded with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: provisions and cattle, and conveyed that welcome succor to the hungry
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: city, managing the matter successfully under protection of a sortie
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from the walls against the bastille of St. Loup. Then Joan began on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Bastard again:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You see here the army?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is here on this side by advice of your council?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now, in God's name, can that wise council explain why it is better to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have it here than it would be to have it in the bottom of the sea?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Dunois made some wandering attempts to explain the inexplicable and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: excuse the inexcusable, but Joan cut him short and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Answer me this, good sir--has the army any value on this side of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: river?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Bastard confessed that it hadn't--that is, in view of the plan of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: campaign which she had devised and decreed.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And yet, knowing this, you had the hardihood to disobey my orders.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Since the army's place is on the other side, will you explain to me how
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it is to get there?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The whole size of the needless muddle was apparent. Evasions were of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: no use; therefore Dunois admitted that there was no way to correct the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: blunder but to send the army all the way back to Blois, and let it begin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over again and come up on the other side this time, according to Joan's
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: original plan.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Any other girl, after winning such a triumph as this over a veteran
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldier of old renown, might have exulted a little and been excusable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for it, but Joan showed no disposition of this sort. She dropped a word
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: or two of grief over the precious time that must be lost, then began at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: once to issue commands for the march back. She sorrowed to see her army
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: go; for she said its heart was great and its enthusiasm high, and that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with it at her back she did not fear to face all the might of England.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: All arrangements having been completed for the return of the main body
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the army, she took the Bastard and La Hire and a thousand men and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: went down to Orleans, where all the town was in a fever of impatience
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to have sight of her face. It was eight in the evening when she and the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: troops rode in at the Burgundy gate, with the Paladin preceding her with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her standard. She was riding a white horse, and she carried in her hand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the sacred sword of Fierbois. You should have seen Orleans then. What
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a picture it was! Such black seas of people, such a starry firmament of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: torches, such roaring whirlwinds of welcome, such booming of bells
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and thundering of cannon! It was as if the world was come to an end.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Everywhere in the glare of the torches one saw rank upon rank of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: upturned white faces, the mouths wide open, shouting, and the unchecked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: tears running down; Joan forged her slow way through the solid masses,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enthusiasm--solemn enthusiasm, one may call it, for the manner of it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: deeper than mere gravity--and she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, it shall be as you will. What are you called?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The man answered with unsmiling simplicity:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They call me the Dwarf, but I think it is more in jest than otherwise."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It made Joan laugh, and she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It has something of that look truly! What is the office of that vast
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ax?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The soldier replied with the same gravity--which must have been born to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him, it sat upon him so naturally:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is to persuade persons to respect France."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan laughed again, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have you given many lessons?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, indeed, yes--many."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "The pupils behaved to suit you, afterward?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes; it made them quiet--quite pleasant and quiet."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I should think it would happen so. Would you like to be my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: man-at-arms?--orderly, sentinel, or something like that?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "If I may!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Then you shall. You shall have proper armor, and shall go on teaching
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: your art. Take one of those led horses there, and follow the staff when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
