text: we move."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: That is how we came by the Dwarf; and a good fellow he was. Joan picked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him out on sight, but it wasn't a mistake; no one could be faithfuler
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: than he was, and he was a devil and the son of a devil when he turned
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself loose with his ax. He was so big that he made the Paladin look
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: like an ordinary man. He liked to like people, therefore people liked
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him. He liked us boys from the start; and he liked the knights, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: liked pretty much everybody he came across; but he thought more of a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: paring of Joan's finger-nail than he did of all the rest of the world
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: put together.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, that is where we got him--stretched on the wain, going to his death,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: poor chap, and nobody to say a good word for him. He was a good find.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Why, the knights treated him almost like an equal--it is the honest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: truth; that is the sort of a man he was. They called him the Bastille
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sometimes, and sometimes they called him Hellfire, which was on account
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of his warm and sumptuous style in battle, and you know they wouldn't
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have given him pet names if they hadn't had a good deal of affection for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To the Dwarf, Joan was France, the spirit of France made flesh--he never
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: got away from that idea that he had started with; and God knows it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the true one. That was a humble eye to see so great a truth where some
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: others failed. To me that seems quite remarkable. And yet, after all,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it was, in a way, just what nations do. When they love a great and noble
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thing, they embody it--they want it so that they can see it with their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eyes; like liberty, for instance. They are not content with the cloudy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: abstract idea, they make a beautiful statue of it, and then their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: beloved idea is substantial and they can look at it and worship it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so it is as I say; to the Dwarf, Joan was our country embodied,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: our country made visible flesh cast in a gracious form. When she stood
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: before others, they saw Joan of Arc, but he saw France.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Sometimes he would speak of her by that name. It shows you how the idea
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was embedded in his mind, and how real it was to him. The world has
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: called our kings by it, but I know of none of them who has had so good a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: right as she to that sublime title.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: When the march past was finished, Joan returned to the front and rode at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the head of the column. When we began to file past those grim bastilles
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and could glimpse the men within, standing to their guns and ready to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: empty death into our ranks, such a faintness came over me and such a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sickness that all things seemed to turn dim and swim before my eyes;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the other boys looked droopy, too, I thought--including the Paladin,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: although I do not know this for certain, because he was ahead of me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and I had to keep my eyes out toward the bastille side, because I could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: wince better when I saw what to wince at.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But Joan was at home--in Paradise, I might say. She sat up straight, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I could see that she was feeling different from me. The awfulest thing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was the silence; there wasn't a sound but the screaking of the saddles,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the measured tramplings, and the sneezing of the horses, afflicted by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the smothering dust-clouds which they kicked up. I wanted to sneeze
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: myself, but it seemed to me that I would rather go unsneezed, or suffer
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: even a bitterer torture, if there is one, than attract attention to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: myself.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was not of a rank to make suggestions, or I would have suggested that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: if we went faster we should get by sooner. It seemed to me that it was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: an ill-judged time to be taking a walk. Just as we were drifting in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that suffocating stillness past a great cannon that stood just within a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: raised portcullis, with nothing between me and it but the moat, a most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: uncommon jackass in there split the world with his bray, and I fell out
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the saddle. Sir Bertrand grabbed me as I went, which was well, for if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: myself. The English warders on the battlements laughed a coarse laugh,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forgetting that every one must begin, and that there had been a time
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The English never uttered a challenge nor fired a shot. It was said
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: vanished in the rest, they feeling certain that the creature was not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: own and try to get around carrying hers out.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: said:

author: Twain, Mark

text: struggling and shouldering each other to get a glimpse of her was so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: great that we could hardly push our way through the streets at all. Her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: new name had gone all about, and was on everybody's lips. The Holy Maid
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: of Vaucouleurs was a forgotten title; the city had claimed her for its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: own, and she was the MAID OF ORLEANS now. It is a happiness to me to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: remember that I heard that name the first time it was ever uttered.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this earth--ah, think how many moldering ages will lie in that gap!

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: house, and saved from death against all hope or probability. They chided
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her for going into the battle and exposing herself to danger during
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all those hours. They could not realize that she had meant to carry her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: BEING WORN out with the long fight, we all slept the rest of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: afternoon away and two or three hours into the night. Then we got up
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: refreshed, and had supper. As for me, I could have been willing to let
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the matter of the ghost drop; and the others were of a like mind, no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: doubt, for they talked diligently of the battle and said nothing of that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other thing. And indeed it was fine and stirring to hear the Paladin
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: rehearse his deeds and see him pile his dead, fifteen here, eighteen
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there, and thirty-five yonder; but this only postponed the trouble; it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: could not do more. He could not go on forever; when he had carried the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bastille by assault and eaten up the garrison there was nothing for it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but to stop, unless Catherine Boucher would give him a new start and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have it all done over again--as we hoped she would, this time--but she was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: otherwise minded. As soon as there was a good opening and a fair chance,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she brought up her unwelcome subject, and we faced it the best we could.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We followed her and her parents to the haunted room at eleven o'clock,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with candles, and also with torches to place in the sockets on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: walls. It was a big house, with very thick walls, and this room was in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a remote part of it which had been left unoccupied for nobody knew how
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: many years, because of its evil repute.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: This was a large room, like a salon, and had a big table in it of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enduring oak and well preserved; but the chair were worm-eaten and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the tapestry on the walls was rotten and discolored by age. The dusty
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: cobwebs under the ceiling had the look of not having had any business
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for a century.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Catherine said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Tradition says that these ghosts have never been seen--they have merely
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: been heard. It is plain that this room was once larger than it is now,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and that the wall at this end was built in some bygone time to make and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fence off a narrow room there. There is no communication anywhere with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that narrow room, and if it exists--and of that there is no reasonable
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: doubt--it has no light and no air, but is an absolute dungeon. Wait where
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: you are, and take note of what happens."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: That was all. Then she and her parents left us. When their footfalls
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: had died out in the distance down the empty stone corridors an uncanny
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: silence and solemnity ensued which was dismaler to me than the mute
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: march past the bastilles. We sat looking vacantly at each other, and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was easy to see that no one there was comfortable. The longer we sat so,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the more deadly still that stillness got to be; and when the wind began
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to moan around the house presently, it made me sick and miserable, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I wished I had been brave enough to be a coward this time, for indeed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it is no proper shame to be afraid of ghosts, seeing how helpless the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: living are in their hands. And then these ghosts were invisible, which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: made the matter the worse, as it seemed to me. They might be in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: room with us at that moment--we could not know. I felt airy touches on my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: shoulders and my hair, and I shrank from them and cringed, and was not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ashamed to show this fear, for I saw the others doing the like, and knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that they were feeling those faint contacts too. As this went on--oh,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: eternities it seemed, the time dragged so drearily--all those faces
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: became as wax, and I seemed sitting with a congress of the dead.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At last, faint and far and weird and slow, came a "boom!--boom!--boom!"--a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: distant bell tolling midnight. When the last stroke died, that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: depressing stillness followed again, and as before I was staring at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: those waxen faces and feeling those airy touches on my hair and my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: shoulders once more.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: One minute--two minutes--three minutes of this, then we heard a long deep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: groan, and everybody sprang up and stood, with his legs quaking. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: came from that little dungeon. There was a pause, then we herd muffled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sobbings, mixed with pitiful ejaculations. Then there was a second
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: voice, low and not distinct, and the one seemed trying to comfort the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: other; and so the two voices went on, with moanings, and soft sobbings,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and, ah, the tones were so full of compassion and sorry and despair!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Indeed, it made one's heart sore to hear it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But those sounds were so real and so human and so moving that the idea
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of ghosts passed straight out of our minds, and Sir Jean de Metz spoke
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with your ax!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: an ox could pass through. We plunged within and held up the torches.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fan.

text: THE NEXT day Joan wanted to go against the enemy again, but it was the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: feast of the Ascension, and the holy council of bandit generals were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: too pious to be willing to profane it with bloodshed. But privately they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: profaned it with plottings, a sort of industry just in their line. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: decided to do the only thing proper to do now in the new circumstances
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the case--feign an attack on the most important bastille on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Orleans side, and then, if the English weakened the far more important
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fortresses on the other side of the river to come to its help, cross in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: force and capture those works. This would give them the bridge and free
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: communication with the Sologne, which was French territory. They decided
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to keep this latter part of the program secret from Joan.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan intruded and took them by surprise. She asked them what they were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about and what they had resolved upon. They said they had resolved to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: attack the most important of the English bastilles on the Orleans side
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: next morning--and there the spokesman stopped. Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, go on."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There is nothing more. That is all."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Am I to believe this? That is to say, am I to believe that you have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lost your wits?" She turned to Dunois, and said, "Bastard, you have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sense, answer me this: if this attack is made and the bastille taken,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: how much better off would we be than we are now?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Bastard hesitated, and then began some rambling talk not quite
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: germane to the question. Joan interrupted him and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "That will not do, good Bastard, you have answered. Since the Bastard is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not able to mention any advantage to be gained by taking that bastille
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and stopping there, it is not likely that any of you could better
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the matter. You waste much time here in inventing plans that lead
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to nothing, and making delays that are a damage. Are you concealing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: something from me? Bastard, this council has a general plan, I take it;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: without going into details, what is it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is the same it was in the beginning, seven months ago--to get
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: provisions for a long siege, then sit down and tire the English out."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "In the name of God! As if seven months was not enough, you want
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to provide for a year of it. Now ye shall drop these pusillanimous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dreams--the English shall go in three days!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Several exclaimed:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, General, General, be prudent!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Be prudent and starve? Do ye call that war? I tell you this, if you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: do not already know it: The new circumstances have changed the face of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: matters. The true point of attack has shifted; it is on the other side
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the river now. One must take the fortifications that command the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: superstition if you must, but you perceive that this child understands
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: to play it!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan had spoken truly; the sagacious English saw that the policy of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the French had undergone a revolution; that the policy of paltering and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dawdling was ended; that in place of taking blows, blows were ready to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: be struck now; therefore they made ready for the new state of things
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by transferring heavy reinforcements to the bastilles of the south bank
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: from those of the north.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The city learned the great news that once more in French history, after
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all these humiliating years, France was going to take the offensive;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that France, so used to retreating, was going to advance; that France,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: so long accustomed to skulking, was going to face about and strike. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: joy of the people passed all bounds. The city walls were black with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them to see the army march out in the morning in that strange new
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: position--its front, not its tail, toward an English camp. You shall
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: itself, when Joan rode out at the head of the host with her banner
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: floating above her.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bastille of the Augustins, the first of the formidable works that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: two charges followed in handsome style; but we were too weak, as yet,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for our main body was still lagging behind. Before we could gather for a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: third assault the garrison of St. Prive were seen coming up to reinforce
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the big bastille. They came on a run, and the Augustins sallied out, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in a panic, and followed us, slashing and slaying, and shouting jeers
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and insults at us.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was doing her best to rally the men, but their wits were gone,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their hearts were dominated for the moment by the old-time dread of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the English. Joan's temper flamed up, and she halted and commanded the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: trumpets to sound the advance. Then she wheeled about and cried out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: enough--follow me!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Away she went, and after her a few dozen who had heard her words and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: been inspired by them. The pursuing force was astonished to see her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sweeping down upon them with this handful of men, and it was their turn
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: now to experience a grisly fright--surely this is a witch, this is a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the matter they turned and fled in a panic.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Our flying squadrons heard the bugle and turned to look; and when they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: saw the Maid's banner speeding in the other direction and the enemy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: scrambling ahead of it in disorder, their courage returned and they came
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: scouring after us.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: La Hire heard it and hurried his force forward and caught up with us
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: just as we were planting our banner again before the ramparts of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Augustins. We were strong enough now. We had a long and tough piece of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: work before us, but we carried it through before night, Joan keeping
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: us hard at it, and she and La Hire saying we were able to take that big
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bastille, and must. The English fought like--well, they fought like the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: English; when that is said, there is no more to say. We made
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with a rush, and planted our standard on its walls.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Augustins was ours. The Tourelles must be ours, too, if we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: would free the bridge and raise the siege. We had achieved one great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: undertaking, Joan was determined to accomplish the other. We must lie on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: our arms where we were, hold fast to what we had got, and be ready
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for business in the morning. So Joan was not minded to let the men be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: demoralized by pillage and riot and carousings; she had the Augustins
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: burned, with all its stores in it, excepting the artillery and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ammunition.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Everybody was tired out with this long day's hard work, and of course
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this was the case with Joan; still, she wanted to stay with the army
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: before the Tourelles, to be ready for the assault in the morning. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: chiefs argued with her, and at last persuaded her to go home and prepare
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for the great work by taking proper rest, and also by having a leech
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: look to a wound which she had received in her foot. So we crossed with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them and went home.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: clanging, everybody shouting, and several people drunk. We never went
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of these pleasant tempests, and so the tempest was always on hand. There
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: TO GET away from the usual crowd of visitors and have a rest, Joan
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: went with Catherine straight to the apartment which the two occupied
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: together, and there they took their supper and there the wound was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dressed. But then, instead of going to bed, Joan, weary as she was, sent
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the Dwarf for me, in spite of Catherine's protests and persuasions. She
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: said she had something on her mind, and must send a courier to Domremy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with a letter for our old Pere Fronte to read to her mother. I came,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and she began to dictate. After some loving words and greetings to her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mother and family, came this:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But the thing which moves me to write now, is to say that when you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: presently hear that I am wounded, you shall give yourself no concern
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about it, and refuse faith to any that shall try to make you believe it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is serious."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She was going on, when Catherine spoke up and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, but it will fright her so to read these words. Strike them out,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan, strike them out, and wait only one day--two days at most--then write
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and say your foot was wounded but is well again--for it surely be well
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: then, or very near it. Don't distress her, Joan; do as I say."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: A laugh like the laugh of the old days, the impulsive free laugh of an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: untroubled spirit, a laugh like a chime of bells, was Joan's answer;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: then she said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "My foot? Why should I write about such a scratch as that? I was not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thinking of it, dear heart."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Child, have you another wound and a worse, and have not spoken of it?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: What have you been dreaming about, that you--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She had jumped up, full of vague fears, to have the leech called back at
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: once, but Joan laid her hand upon her arm and made her sit down again,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "There, now, be tranquil, there is no other wound, as yet; I am writing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: about one which I shall get when we storm that bastille tomorrow."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Catherine had the look of one who is trying to understand a puzzling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: proposition but cannot quite do it. She said, in a distraught fashion:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "A wound which you are going to get? But--but why grieve your mother when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it--when it may not happen?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "May not? Why, it will."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The puzzle was a puzzle still. Catherine said in that same abstracted
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: way as before:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Will. It is a strong word. I cannot seem to--my mind is not able to take
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hold of this. Oh, Joan, such a presentiment is a dreadful thing--it takes
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one's peace and courage all away. Cast it from you!--drive it out! It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will make your whole night miserable, and to no good; for we will hope--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But it isn't a presentiment--it is a fact. And it will not make
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: me miserable. It is uncertainties that do that, but this is not an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: uncertainty."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Joan, do you know it is going to happen?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, I know it. My Voices told me."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah," said Catherine, resignedly, "if they told you--But are you sure it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was they?--quite sure?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, quite. It will happen--there is no doubt."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is dreadful! Since when have you know it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Since--I think it is several weeks." Joan turned to me. "Louis, you will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: remember. How long is it?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Your Excellency spoke of it first to the King, in Chinon," I answered;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "that was as much as seven weeks ago. You spoke of it again the 20th of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: April, and also the 22d, two weeks ago, as I see by my record here."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: These marvels disturbed Catherine profoundly, but I had long ceased
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to be surprised at them. One can get used to anything in this world.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Catherine said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always? There has been no mistake, and no confusion?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Then you shall not go a step out of this house till that awful day is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: gone by! You will not dream of it, Joan, will you?--promise that you will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It would not help the matter, dear good friend. The wound is to come,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and come to-morrow. If I do not seek it, it will seek me. My duty calls
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: do better than that."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: France--hearten her soldiers for battle and victory." She thought a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

author: Twain, Mark

text: of Orleans!" That was the cry; I heard it a hundred thousand times.

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Even those insects were sobered by her impassioned words. The King
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: looked very grave--grave, and strongly impressed. His eyes lit suddenly
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with an eloquent fire, and he rose and drew his sword and raised it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: aloft; then he brought it slowly down upon Joan's shoulder and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, thou art so simple, so true, so great, so noble--and by this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: accolade I join thee to the nobility of France, thy fitting place! And
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for thy sake I do hereby ennoble all thy family and all thy kin; and all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their descendants born in wedlock, not only in the male but also in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: female line. And more!--more! To distinguish thy house and honor it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: above all others, we add a privilege never accorded to any before in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: history of these dominions: the females of thy line shall have and hold
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the right to ennoble their husbands when these shall be of inferior
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: degree." [Astonishment and envy flared up in every countenance when the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: words were uttered which conferred this extraordinary grace. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: King paused and looked around upon these signs with quite evident
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: satisfaction.] "Rise, Joan of Arc, now and henceforth surnamed Du Lis,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in grateful acknowledgment of the good blow which you have struck
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for the lilies of France; and they, and the royal crown, and your own
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: victorious sword, fit and fair company for each other, shall be grouped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in you escutcheon and be and remain the symbol of your high nobility
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forever."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: As my Lady Du Lis rose, the gilded children of privilege pressed forward
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to welcome her to their sacred ranks and call her by her new name; but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she was troubled, and said these honors were not meet for one of her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: lowly birth and station, and by their kind grace she would remain simple
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc, nothing more--and so be called.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Nothing more! As if there could be anything more, anything higher,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: anything greater. My Lady Du Lis--why, it was tinsel, petty, perishable.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But, JOAN OF ARC! The mere sound of it sets one's pulses leaping.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 24 Tinsel Trappings of Nobility
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: IT WAS vexatious to see what a to-do the whole town, and next the whole
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: country, made over the news. Joan of Arc ennobled by the King! People
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: went dizzy with wonder and delight over it. You cannot imagine how she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was gaped at, stared at, envied. Why, one would have supposed that some
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: great and fortunate thing had happened to her. But we did not think any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: great things of it. To our minds no mere human hand could add a glory to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc. To us she was the sun soaring in the heavens, and her new
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nobility a candle atop of it; to us it was swallowed up and lost in her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: own light. And she was as indifferent to it and as unconscious of it as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the other sun would have been.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But it was different with her brothers. They were proud and happy in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: their new dignity, which was quite natural. And Joan was glad it had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: been conferred, when she saw how pleased they were. It was a clever
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thought in the King to outflank her scruples by marching on them under
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: shelter of her love for her family and her kin.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Jean and Pierre sported their coats-of-arms right away; and their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: society was courted by everybody, the nobles and commons alike. The
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Standard-Bearer said, with some touch of bitterness, that he could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: see that they just felt good to be alive, they were so soaked with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: comfort of their glory; and didn't like to sleep at all, because when
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they were asleep they didn't know they were noble, and so sleep was a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: clean loss of time. And then he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "They can't take precedence of me in military functions and state
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ceremonies, but when it comes to civil ones and society affairs I judge
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they'll cuddle coolly in behind you and the knights, and Noel and I will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have to walk behind them--hey?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes," I said, "I think you are right."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I was just afraid of it--just afraid of it," said the Standard-Bearer,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with a sigh. "Afraid of it? I'm talking like a fool; of course I knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it. Yes, I was talking like a fool."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Noel Rainguesson said, musingly:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, I noticed something natural about the tone of it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We others laughed.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, you did, did you? You think you are very clever, don't you? I'll
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: take and wring your neck for you one of these days, Noel Rainguesson."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Sieur de Metz said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Paladin, your fears haven't reached the top notch. They are away
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: below the grand possibilities. Didn't it occur to you that in civil
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and society functions they will take precedence of all the rest of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: personal staff--every one of us?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, come!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You'll find it's so. Look at their escutcheon. Its chiefest feature is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the lilies of France. It's royal, man, royal--do you understand the size
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of that? The lilies are there by authority of the King--do you understand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the size of that? Though not in detail and in entirety, they do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: nevertheless substantially quarter the arms of France in their coat.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Imagine it! consider it! measure the magnitude of it! We walk in front
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of those boys? Bless you, we've done that for the last time. In my
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: opinion there isn't a lay lord in this whole region that can walk in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: front of them, except the Duke d'Alencon, prince of the blood."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: You could have knocked the Paladin down with a feather. He seemed to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: actually turn pale. He worked his lips a moment without getting anything
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out; then it came:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I didn't know that, nor the half of it; how could I? I've been an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: idiot. I see it now--I've been an idiot. I met them this morning, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sung out hello to them just as I would to anybody. I didn't mean to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: be ill-mannered, but I didn't know the half of this that you've been
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: telling. I've been an ass. Yes, that is all there is to it--I've been an
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ass."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Noel Rainguesson said, in a kind of weary way:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, that is likely enough; but I don't see why you should seem
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: surprised at it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You don't, don't you? Well, why don't you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Because I don't see any novelty about it. With some people it is a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: condition which is present all the time. Now you take a condition which
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is present all the time, and the results of that condition will be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: uniform; this uniformity of result will in time become monotonous;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: monotonousness, by the law of its being, is fatiguing. If you had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: manifested fatigue upon noticing that you had been an ass, that would
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: have been logical, that would have been rational; whereas it seems to me
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that to manifest surprise was to be again an ass, because the condition
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of intellect that can enable a person to be surprised and stirred by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: inert monotonousness is a--"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now that is enough, Noel Rainguesson; stop where you are, before you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: get yourself into trouble. And don't bother me any more for some days or
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a week an it please you, for I cannot abide your clack."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Come, I like that! I didn't want to talk. I tried to get out of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: talking. If you didn't want to hear my clack, what did you keep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: intruding your conversation on me for?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I? I never dreamed of such a thing."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Well, you did it, anyway. And I have a right to feel hurt, and I do
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: feel hurt, to have you treat me so. It seems to me that when a person
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: goads, and crowds, and in a manner forces another person to talk, it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: neither very fair nor very good-mannered to call what he says clack."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Oh, snuffle--do! and break your heart, you poor thing. Somebody fetch
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this sick doll a sugar-rag. Look you, Sir Jean de Metz, do you feel
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: absolutely certain about that thing?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "What thing?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Why, that Jean and Pierre are going to take precedence of all the lay
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: noblesse hereabouts except the Duke d'Alencon?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I think there is not a doubt of it."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Standard-Bearer was deep in thoughts and dreams a few moments, then
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the silk-and-velvet expanse of his vast breast rose and fell with a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sigh, and he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Dear, dear, what a lift it is! It just shows what luck can do. Well, I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: don't care. I shouldn't care to be a painted accident--I shouldn't value
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it. I am prouder to have climbed up to where I am just by sheer natural
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: merit than I would be to ride the very sun in the zenith and have to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: reflect that I was nothing but a poor little accident, and got shot up
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there out of somebody else's catapult. To me, merit is everything--in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fact, the only thing. All else is dross."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Just then the bugles blew the assembly, and that cut our talk short.

author: Twain, Mark
