text: Chapter 25 At Last--Forward!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: THE DAYS began to waste away--and nothing decided, nothing done. The army
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was full of zeal, but it was also hungry. It got no pay, the treasury
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was getting empty, it was becoming impossible to feed it; under pressure
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of privation it began to fall apart and disperse--which pleased the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: trifling court exceedingly. Joan's distress was pitiful to see. She was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: obliged to stand helpless while her victorious army dissolved away until
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hardly the skeleton of it was left.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At last one day she went to the Castle of Loches, where the King was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: idling. She found him consulting with three of his councilors, Robert le
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Maton, a former Chancellor of France, Christophe d'Harcourt, and Gerard
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Machet. The Bastard of Orleans was present also, and it is through him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that we know what happened. Joan threw herself at the King's feet and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: embraced his knees, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Noble Dauphin, prithee hold no more of these long and numerous
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: councils, but come, and come quickly, to Rheims and receive your crown."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Christophe d'Harcourt asked:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Is it your Voices that command you to say that to the King?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, and urgently."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Then will you not tell us in the King's presence in what way the Voices
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: communicate with you?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was another sly attempt to trap Joan into indiscreet admissions and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dangerous pretensions. But nothing came of it. Joan's answer was simple
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and straightforward, and the smooth Bishop was not able to find any
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fault with it. She said that when she met with people who doubted the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: truth of her mission she went aside and prayed, complaining of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: distrust of these, and then the comforting Voices were heard at her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ear saying, soft and low, "Go forward, Daughter of God, and I will help
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thee." Then she added, "When I hear that, the joy in my heart, oh, it is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: insupportable!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Bastard said that when she said these words her face lit up as with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a flame, and she was like one in an ecstasy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan pleaded, persuaded, reasoned; gaining ground little by little, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: opposed step by step by the council. She begged, she implored, leave to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: march. When they could answer nothing further, they granted that perhaps
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it had been a mistake to let the army waste away, but how could we help
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it now? how could we march without an army?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Raise one!" said Joan.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "But it will take six weeks."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No matter--begin! let us begin!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is too late. Without doubt the Duke of Bedford has been gathering
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: troops to push to the succor of his strongholds on the Loire."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes, while we have been disbanding ours--and pity 'tis. But we must
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: throw away no more time; we must bestir ourselves."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The King objected that he could not venture toward Rheims with those
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: strong places on the Loire in his path. But Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "We will break them up. Then you can march."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: With that plan the King was willing to venture assent. He could sit
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: around out of danger while the road was being cleared.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan came back in great spirits. Straightway everything was stirring.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Proclamations were issued calling for men, a recruiting-camp was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: established at Selles in Berry, and the commons and the nobles began to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: flock to it with enthusiasm.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: A deal of the month of May had been wasted; and yet by the 6th of June
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan had swept together a new army and was ready to march. She had eight
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thousand men. Think of that. Think of gathering together such a body
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: as that in that little region. And these were veteran soldiers, too. In
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fact, most of the men in France were soldiers, when you came to that;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for the wars had lasted generations now. Yes, most Frenchmen were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: soldiers; and admirable runners, too, both by practice and inheritance;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they had done next to nothing but run for near a century. But that was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not their fault. They had had no fair and proper leadership--at least
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: leaders with a fair and proper chance. Away back, King and Court got the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: habit of being treacherous to the leaders; then the leaders easily
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: got the habit of disobeying the King and going their own way, each for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: himself and nobody for the lot. Nobody could win victories that way.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Hence, running became the habit of the French troops, and no wonder. Yet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all that those troops needed in order to be good fighters was a leader
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: who would attend strictly to business--a leader with all authority in his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hands in place of a tenth of it along with nine other generals equipped
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with an equal tenth apiece. They had a leader rightly clothed with
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: authority now, and with a head and heart bent on war of the most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: intensely businesslike and earnest sort--and there would be results. No
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: doubt of that. They had Joan of Arc; and under that leadership their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: legs would lose the art and mystery of running.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, Joan was in great spirits. She was here and there and everywhere,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all over the camp, by day and by night, pushing things. And wherever she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: came charging down the lines, reviewing the troops, it was good to hear
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them break out and cheer. And nobody could help cheering, she was such
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a vision of young bloom and beauty and grace, and such an incarnation of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pluck and life and go! she was growing more and more ideally beautiful
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: every day, as was plain to be seen--and these were days of development;
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: for she was well past seventeen now--in fact, she was getting close upon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: seventeen and a half--indeed, just a little woman, as you may say.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The two young Counts de Laval arrived one day--fine young fellows allied
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to the greatest and most illustrious houses of France; and they could
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: not rest till they had seen Joan of Arc. So the King sent for them and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: presented them to her, and you may believe she filled the bill of their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: expectations. When they heard that rich voice of hers they must have
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thought it was a flute; and when they saw her deep eyes and her face,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the soul that looked out of that face, you could see that the sight
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of her stirred them like a poem, like lofty eloquence, like martial
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: music. One of them wrote home to his people, and in his letter he said,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It seemed something divine to see her and hear her." Ah, yes, and it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was a true word. Truer word was never spoken.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He saw her when she was ready to begin her march and open the campaign,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and this is what he said about it:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "She was clothed all in white armor save her head, and in her hand she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: carried a little battle-ax; and when she was ready to mount her great
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: black horse he reared and plunged and would not let her. Then she said,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: 'Lead him to the cross.' This cross was in front of the church close by.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: So they led him there. Then she mounted, and he never budged, any more
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: than if he had been tied. Then she turned toward the door of the church
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and said, in her soft womanly voice, 'You, priests and people of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Church, make processions and pray to God for us!' Then she spurred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: away, under her standard, with her little ax in her hand, crying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: 'Forward--march!' One of her brothers, who came eight days ago, departed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: with her; and he also was clad all in white armor."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I was there, and I saw it, too; saw it all, just as he pictures it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And I see it yet--the little battle-ax, the dainty plumed cap, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: white armor--all in the soft June afternoon; I see it just as if it were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: yesterday. And I rode with the staff--the personal staff--the staff of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: That young count was dying to go, too, but the King held him back for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the present. But Joan had made him a promise. In his letter he said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "She told me that when the King starts for Rheims I shall go with him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: But God grant I may not have to wait till then, but may have a part in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the battles!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: She made him that promise when she was taking leave of my lady the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Duchess d'Alencon. The duchess was exacting a promise, so it seemed a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: proper time for others to do the like. The duchess was troubled for her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: husband, for she foresaw desperate fighting; and she held Joan to her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: breast, and stroked her hair lovingly, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "You must watch over him, dear, and take care of him, and send him
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: back to me safe. I require it of you; I will not let you go till you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: promise."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I give you the promise with all my heart; and it is not just words, it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: is a promise; you shall have him back without a hurt. Do you believe?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And are you satisfied with me now?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they parted.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: and more and longer; yet was not thought of for that office, and I so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: famished for it. Ah, she was so beautiful, and oh, so sweet! I had loved
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her the first day I ever saw her, and from that day forth she was sacred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to me. I have carried her image in my heart for sixty-three years--all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

text: THIS TIME, as before, the King's last command to the generals was this:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "See to it that you do nothing without the sanction of the Maid." And
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: this time the command was obeyed; and would continue to be obeyed all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: through the coming great days of the Loire campaign.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: That was a change! That was new! It broke the traditions. It shows you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: what sort of a reputation as a commander-in-chief the child had made for
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: judge spoke of her as "this marvelous child"? It was the right name, you
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: see.

author: Twain, Mark

author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1

text: dashing war tactics and earnestly desired to modify them. And so, during

author: Twain, Mark

text: "There are some that never know how to change. Circumstances may change,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: but those people are never able to see that they have got to change too,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to meet those circumstances. All that they know is the one beaten
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: track that their fathers and grandfathers have followed and that they
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: themselves have followed in their turn. If an earthquake come and rip
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the land to chaos, and that beaten track now lead over precipices and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: into morasses, those people can't learn that they must strike out a new
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: road--no; they will march stupidly along and follow the old one, to death
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and perdition. Men, there's a new state of things; and a surpassing
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: military genius has perceived it with her clear eye. And a new road is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: required, and that same clear eye has noted where it must go, and has
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: marked it out for us. The man does not live, never has lived, never
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will live, that can improve upon it! The old state of things was defeat,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: defeat, defeat--and by consequence we had troops with no dash, no heart,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: no hope. Would you assault stone walls with such? No--there was but one
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: way with that kind: sit down before a place and wait, wait--starve it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: out, if you could. The new case is the very opposite; it is this: men
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all on fire with pluck and dash and vim and fury and energy--a restrained
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: conflagration! What would you do with it? Hold it down and let it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: smolder and perish and go out? What would Joan of Arc do with it? Turn
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it loose, by the Lord God of heaven and earth, and let it swallow up the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: foe in the whirlwind of its fires! Nothing shows the splendor and wisdom
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of her military genius like her instant comprehension of the size of the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: change which has come about, and her instant perception of the right and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: only right way to take advantage of it. With her is no sitting down and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: starving out; no dilly-dallying and fooling around; no lazying, loafing,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and going to sleep; no, it is storm! storm! storm! and still storm!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: storm! storm! and forever storm! storm! storm! hunt the enemy to his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hole, then turn her French hurricanes loose and carry him by storm!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And that is my sort! Jargeau? What of Jargeau, with its battlements and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: towers, its devastating artillery, its seven thousand picked veterans?
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc is to the fore, and by the splendor of God its fate is
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sealed!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Oh, he carried them. There was not another word said about persuading
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan to change her tactics. They sat talking comfortably enough after
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: By and by Joan entered, and they rose and saluted with their swords, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she asked what their pleasure might be. La Hire said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "It is settled, my General. The matter concerned Jargeau. There were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: some who thought we could not take the place."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan laughed her pleasant laugh, her merry, carefree laugh; the laugh
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that rippled so buoyantly from her lips and made old people feel young
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: again to hear it; and she said to the company:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Have no fears--indeed, there is no need nor any occasion for them. We
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: will strike the English boldly by assault, and you will see." Then a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: faraway look came into her eyes, and I think that a picture of her home
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: drifted across the vision of her mind; for she said very gently, and as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one who muses, "But that I know God guides us and will give us success,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I had liefer keep sheep than endure these perils."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We had a homelike farewell supper that evening--just the personal staff
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the family. Joan had to miss it; for the city had given a banquet in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: her honor, and she had gone there in state with the Grand Staff, through
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: a riot of joy-bells and a sparkling Milky Way of illuminations.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: After supper some lively young folk whom we knew came in, and we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: presently forgot that we were soldiers, and only remembered that we
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were boys and girls and full of animal spirits and long-pent fun; and so
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there was dancing, and games, and romps, and screams of laughter--just as
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: extravagant and innocent and noisy a good time as ever I had in my life.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Dear, dear, how long ago it was!--and I was young then. And outside, all
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the while, was the measured tramp of marching battalions, belated odds
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and ends of the French power gathering for the morrow's tragedy on the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: grim stage of war. Yes, in those days we had those contrasts side by
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: side. And as I passed along to bed there was another one: the big Dwarf,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in brave new armor, sat sentry at Joan's door--the stern Spirit of War
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: made flesh, as it were--and on his ample shoulder was curled a kitten
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: asleep.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Chapter 27 How Joan Took Jargeau
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: WE MADE a gallant show next day when we filed out through the frowning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: gates of Orleans, with banners flying and Joan and the Grand Staff in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the van of the long column. Those two young De Lavals were come now, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: were joined to the Grand Staff. Which was well; war being their proper
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: trade, for they were grandsons of that illustrious fighter Bertrand du
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Guesclin, Constable of France in earlier days. Louis de Bourbon, the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Marshal de Rais, and the Vidame de Chartres were added also. We had a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: right to feel a little uneasy, for we knew that a force of five thousand
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: men was on its way under Sir John Fastolfe to reinforce Jargeau, but I
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: think we were not uneasy, nevertheless. In truth, that force was not yet
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in our neighborhood. Sir John was loitering; for some reason or other he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was not hurrying. He was losing precious time--four days at Etampes, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: four more at Janville.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We reached Jargeau and began business at once. Joan sent forward a heavy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: force which hurled itself against the outworks in handsome style, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: gained a footing and fought hard to keep it; but it presently began to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fall back before a sortie from the city. Seeing this, Joan raised her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: battle-cry and led a new assault herself under a furious artillery fire.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Paladin was struck down at her side wounded, but she snatched her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: standard from his failing hand and plunged on through the ruck of flying
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: missiles, cheering her men with encouraging cries; and then for a good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: time one had turmoil, and clash of steel, and collision and confusion
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of struggling multitudes, and the hoarse bellowing of the guns; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: then the hiding of it all under a rolling firmament of smoke--a firmament
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: through which veiled vacancies appeared for a moment now and then,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: giving fitful dim glimpses of the wild tragedy enacting beyond; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always at these times one caught sight of that slight figure in white
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mail which was the center and soul of our hope and trust, and whenever
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we saw that, with its back to us and its face to the fight, we knew that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: all was well. At last a great shout went up--a joyous roar of shoutings,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in fact--and that was sign sufficient that the faubourgs were ours.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, they were ours; the enemy had been driven back within the walls. On
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the ground which Joan had won we camped; for night was coming on.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan sent a summons to the English, promising that if they surrendered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: she would allow them to go in peace and take their horses with them.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Nobody knew that she could take that strong place, but she knew it--knew
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it well; yet she offered that grace--offered it in a time when such a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thing was unknown in war; in a time when it was custom and usage to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: massacre the garrison and the inhabitants of captured cities without
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: pity or compunction--yes, even to the harmless women and children
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sometimes. There are neighbors all about you who well remember the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: unspeakable atrocities which Charles the Bold inflicted upon the men and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: women and children of Dinant when he took that place some years ago. It
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was a unique and kindly grace which Joan offered that garrison; but that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was her way, that was her loving and merciful nature--she always did her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: best to save her enemy's life and his soldierly pride when she had the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mastery of him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The English asked fifteen days' armistice to consider the proposal
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in. And Fastolfe coming with five thousand men! Joan said no. But she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: offered another grace: they might take both their horses and their
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: side-arms--but they must go within the hour.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Well, those bronzed English veterans were pretty hard-headed folk. They
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: declined again. Then Joan gave command that her army be made ready to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: move to the assault at nine in the morning. Considering the deal of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: marching and fighting which the men had done that day, D'Alencon thought
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the hour rather early; but Joan said it was best so, and so must be
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: obeyed. Then she burst out with one of those enthusiasms which were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: always burning in her when battle was imminent, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Work! work! and God will work with us!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Yes, one might say that her motto was "Work! stick to it; keep on
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: working!" for in war she never knew what indolence was. And whoever will
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: take that motto and live by it will likely to succeed. There's many a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: way to win in this world, but none of them is worth much without good
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hard work back out of it.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I think we should have lost our big Standard-Bearer that day, if our
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: bigger Dwarf had not been at hand to bring him out of the melee when he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was wounded. He was unconscious, and would have been trampled to death
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: by our own horse, if the Dwarf had not promptly rescued him and haled
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: him to the rear and safety. He recovered, and was himself again after
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: two or three hours; and then he was happy and proud, and made the most
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of his wound, and went swaggering around in his bandages showing off
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: like an innocent big-child--which was just what he was. He was prouder of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: being wounded than a really modest person would be of being killed. But
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: there was no harm in his vanity, and nobody minded it. He said he was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hit by a stone from a catapult--a stone the size of a man's head. But
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the stone grew, of course. Before he got through with it he was claiming
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that the enemy had flung a building at him.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Let him alone," said Noel Rainguesson. "Don't interrupt his processes.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: To-morrow it will be a cathedral."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He said that privately. And, sure enough, to-morrow it was a cathedral.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: I never saw anybody with such an abandoned imagination.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was abroad at the crack of dawn, galloping here and there and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: yonder, examining the situation minutely, and choosing what she
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: considered the most effective positions for her artillery; and with such
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: admiration of it still survived in his memory when his testimony was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: taken at the Rehabilitation, a quarter of a century later.

author: Twain, Mark

text: In this testimony the Duke d'Alencon said that at Jargeau that morning
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of the 12th of June she made her dispositions not like a novice, but
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "with the sure and clear judgment of a trained general of twenty or
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: thirty years' experience."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The veteran captains of the armies of France said she was great in war
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in all ways, but greatest of all in her genius for posting and handling
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: artillery.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Who taught the shepherd-girl to do these marvels--she who could not read,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and had had no opportunity to study the complex arts of war? I do not
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: know any way to solve such a baffling riddle as that, there being no
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: precedent for it, nothing in history to compare it with and examine
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: it by. For in history there is no great general, however gifted, who
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: arrived at success otherwise than through able teaching and hard study
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and some experience. It is a riddle which will never be guessed. I think
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: these vast powers and capacities were born in her, and that she applied
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them by an intuition which could not err.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: At eight o'clock all movement ceased, and with it all sounds, all noise.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: A mute expectancy reigned. The stillness was something awful--because it
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: meant so much. There was no air stirring. The flags on the towers and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ramparts hung straight down like tassels. Wherever one saw a person,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: that person had stopped what he was doing, and was in a waiting
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: attitude, a listening attitude. We were on a commanding spot, clustered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: around Joan. Not far from us, on every hand, were the lanes and humble
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: dwellings of these outlying suburbs. Many people were visible--all were
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: listening, not one was moving. A man had placed a nail; he was about
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to fasten something with it to the door-post of his shop--but he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stopped. There was his hand reaching up holding the nail; and there
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was his other hand in the act of striking with the hammer; but he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: forgotten everything--his head was turned aside listening. Even children
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: unconsciously stopped in their play; I saw a little boy with his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hoop-stick pointed slanting toward the ground in the act of steering the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: hoop around the corner; and so he had stopped and was listening--the hoop
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was rolling away, doing its own steering. I saw a young girl prettily
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: framed in an open window, a watering-pot in her hand and window-boxes of
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: red flowers under its spout--but the water had ceased to flow; the girl
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was listening. Everywhere were these impressive petrified forms; and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: everywhere was suspended movement and that awful stillness.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan of Arc raised her sword in the air. At the signal, the silence was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: torn to rags; cannon after cannon vomited flames and smoke and delivered
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: its quaking thunders; and we saw answering tongues of fire dart from the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: towers and walls of the city, accompanied by answering deep thunders,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and in a minute the walls and the towers disappeared, and in their place
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stood vast banks and pyramids of snowy smoke, motionless in the dead
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: air. The startled girl dropped her watering-pot and clasped her hands
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: together, and at that moment a stone cannon-ball crashed through her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: fair body.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The great artillery duel went on, each side hammering away with all its
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: might; and it was splendid for smoke and noise, and most exalting to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: one's spirits. The poor little town around about us suffered cruelly.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The cannon-balls tore through its slight buildings, wrecking them as if
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they had been built of cards; and every moment or two one would see a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: huge rock come curving through the upper air above the smoke-clouds and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: go plunging down through the roofs. Fire broke out, and columns of flame
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and smoke rose toward the sky.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Presently the artillery concussions changed the weather. The sky became
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: overcast, and a strong wind rose and blew away the smoke that hid the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: English fortresses.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then the spectacle was fine; turreted gray walls and towers, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: streaming bright flags, and jets of red fire and gushes of white smoke
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: in long rows, all standing out with sharp vividness against the deep
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: leaden background of the sky; and then the whizzing missiles began to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: knock up the dirt all around us, and I felt no more interest in the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: scenery. There was one English gun that was getting our position down
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: finer and finer all the time. Presently Joan pointed to it and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Fair duke, step out of your tracks, or that machine will kill you."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Duke d'Alencon did as he was bid; but Monsieur du Lude rashly took
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: his place, and that cannon tore his head off in a moment.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Joan was watching all along for the right time to order the assault. At
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: last, about nine o'clock, she cried out:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Now--to the assault!" and the buglers blew the charge.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Instantly we saw the body of men that had been appointed to this service
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: move forward toward a point where the concentrated fire of our guns had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crumbled the upper half of a broad stretch of wall to ruins; we saw this
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: force descend into the ditch and begin to plant the scaling-ladders.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: We were soon with them. The Lieutenant-General thought the assault
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: premature. But Joan said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Ah, gentle duke, are you afraid? Do you not know that I have promised
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to send you home safe?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was warm work in the ditches. The walls were crowded with men, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: they poured avalanches of stones down upon us. There was one gigantic
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Englishman who did us more hurt than any dozen of his brethren.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He always dominated the places easiest of assault, and flung down
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: exceedingly troublesome big stones which smashed men and ladders
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: both--then he would near burst himself with laughing over what he had
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: done. But the duke settled accounts with him. He went and found the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: famous cannoneer, Jean le Lorrain, and said:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Train your gun--kill me this demon."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: He did it with the first shot. He hit the Englishman fair in the breast
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and knocked him backward into the city.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The enemy's resistance was so effective and so stubborn that our people
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: began to show signs of doubt and dismay. Seeing this, Joan raised her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: inspiring battle-cry and descended into the fosse herself, the Dwarf
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: helping her and the Paladin sticking bravely at her side with the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: standard. She started up a scaling-ladder, but a great stone flung from
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: above came crashing down upon her helmet and stretched her, wounded and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: stunned, upon the ground. But only for a moment. The Dwarf stood her
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: upon her feet, and straightway she started up the ladder again, crying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "To the assault, friends, to the assault--the English are ours! It is the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: appointed hour!"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: There was a grand rush, and a fierce roar of war-cries, and we swarmed
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: over the ramparts like ants. The garrison fled, we pursued; Jargeau was
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: ours!
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: The Earl of Suffolk was hemmed in and surrounded, and the Duke d'Alencon
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: and the Bastard of Orleans demanded that he surrender himself. But he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was a proud nobleman and came of a proud race. He refused to yield his
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: sword to subordinates, saying:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "I will die rather. I will surrender to the Maid of Orleans alone, and
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: to no other."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And so he did; and was courteously and honorably used by her.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: His two brothers retreated, fighting step by step, toward the bridge,
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: we pressing their despairing forces and cutting them down by scores.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Arrived on the bridge, the slaughter still continued. Alexander de la
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Pole was pushed overboard or fell over, and was drowned. Eleven hundred
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: men had fallen; John de la Pole decided to give up the struggle. But he
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: was nearly as proud and particular as his brother of Suffolk as to whom
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: he would surrender to. The French officer nearest at hand was Guillaume
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Renault, who was pressing him closely. Sir John said to him:
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Are you a gentleman?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "Yes."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "And a knight?"
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: "No."
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: Then Sir John knighted him himself there on the bridge, giving him the
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: accolade with English coolness and tranquillity in the midst of that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: storm of slaughter and mutilation; and then bowing with high courtesy
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: took the sword by the blade and laid the hilt of it in the man's hand in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: token of surrender. Ah, yes, a proud tribe, those De la Poles.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: It was a grand day, a memorable day, a most splendid victory. We had a
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: crowd of prisoners, but Joan would not allow them to be hurt. We took
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: them with us and marched into Orleans next day through the usual tempest
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: of welcome and joy.
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: And this time there was a new tribute to our leader. From everywhere in
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: the packed streets the new recruits squeezed their way to her side to
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: touch the sword of Joan of Arc, and draw from it somewhat of that
title: Personal Recollections of Joan of Arc — Volume 1
author: Twain, Mark

text: mysterious quality which made it invincible.
